editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Westward ho as it hath been divers times acted by the children of Paul's.
Written by Tho. Decker, and John Webster.
Printed at London, and to be sold by John Hodget● dwelling in Paul's churchyard. 1607.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Birdlime.
sp.p: Stay Taylour, this is the house, pray thee look the gown be not ruffled: as for the jewels and precious stones, I know where to find them ready presently. She that must wear this gown if she will receive it, is master Justiniano's wife (The Italian merchant) my good old lord and master, that hath been a tilter this twenty year, hath sent it. Mum tailor, you are a kind of bawd. Taylor, if this gentlewoman's husband should chance to be in the way now, you shall tell him that I keep a hothouse in gunpowder alley (Near crouched friars) and that I have brought home his wife's foul linen, and to colour my knavery the better, I have here three or four kinds of complexion, which I will make show of to sell unto her: the young gentlewoman hath a good city wit, I can tell you, she hath red in the Italian courtier, that it is a special ornament to gentlewomen to have skill in painting.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: Is my lord acquainted with her?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: O, I.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: Faith mistress Birdlime I do not commend my lord's choice so well: now methinks he were better to set up a dairy, and to keep half a score of lusty wholesome honest country wenches.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Honest country wenches, in what hundred shall a man find two of that simple virtue?

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: Or to love some lady, there were equality and coherence.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.p: Taylor, you talk like an ass, I tell thee there is equality enough between a lady and a city dame, if their hair be but of a colour: name you any one thing that your citizens wife coms sho●t of to your lady. They have as pure linen, as choice painting, love green greese in spring, mallard and teal in the fall, and woodcock in winter. Your citizen's wife learns nothing but fopperies of your lady, but your lady or justice-a-peace madam, carries high wit from the city, namely, to receive all and pay all: to awe their husbands, to check their husbands, to control their husbands; nay, they have the trick on't to be sick for a new gown, or a carcanet, or a diamond, or so: and I wist this is better wit, than to learn how to wear a Scotch farthingale: nay more.
Here comes one of the servants: you remember tailor that I am deaf: observe that.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: I thou art in that like one of our young gulls, that will not understand any wrong is done him, because he dares not answer it.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: By your leave bachelor: is the gentlewoman your mistress stirring?

sp.speaker: Prentise
sp.p: Yes she is moving.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: What says he?

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: She is up.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Where's the gentleman your master, pray you?

sp.speaker: Prentise
sp.p: Where many women desire to have their husbands, abroad.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: I am very thick of hearing.

sp.speaker: Prentise
sp.p: Why abroad? you smell of the bawd.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: I pray you tell her here's an old gentlewoman would speak with her.

sp.speaker: Prentise
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: What, will you be deaf to the gentlewoman when she comes to?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: O no, she's acquainted well enough with my knavery.
She comes.
How do you sweet lady?

sp.speaker: Merchant wife.
sp.p: Lady.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: By god's me I hope to call you lady ear you die, what mistress do you sleep well on nights.

sp.speaker: M. wife.
sp.p: Sleep, I as quietly as a client having great business with lawyers.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.p: Come, I am come to you about the old suit: my good lord and master hath sent you a velvet gown hear: do you like the colour? three pile, a pretty fantastical trimming, I would god you would say it by my troth. I dreamt last night, you looked so prettily, so sweetly, methought so like the wisest lady of them all, in a velvet gown.

sp.speaker: M. wife.
sp.p: What's the forepart?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: A very pretty stuff, I know not the name of your forepart, but 'tis of a hair colour.

sp.speaker: M. wife.
sp.p: That it was my hard fortune, being so well brought up, having so great a portion to my marriage, to match so unluckily? Why my husband and his whole credit is not worth my apparel, well, I shall undergo a strange report in leaving my husband.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Tush, if you respect your credit, never think of that, for beauty covets tich apparell, choice diet, excellent physic, no German clock no mathematical engine: whatsoever requires so much reparation as a woman's face, and what means hath your husband to allow sweet doctor glister-pipe, his pension. I have heard that you have threescore smocks, that cost three pounds a smock, will these smocks ever hold out with your husband? no, your linen and your apparel must turn over a new-leaf ▪ I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: O admirable bawd? O excellent Birdline?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p:
I have heard he loved you before you were married intyrely, what of that? I have ever found it most true in mine own experience, that they which are most violent dotards before their marriage are most voluntary cuckolds after. Many are honest, either because they have not wist, or because they have ▪ not opportunity to be dishonest, and this Italian your husband's countryman, holds it impossible any of
their ladies should be excellent witty, and not make the uttermost use of their beauty, will you be a fool then?

sp.speaker: M. wife
sp.p: Thou dost persuade me to ill, very well.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: You are nice and peevish, how long will you hold out think you? not so long as Ostend. Enter Justiniano's the merchant. 'Passion of me, your husband? Remember that I am deaf, and that I come to sell you complexion: truly mistress I will deal very reasonably with you.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: What are you? Say ye?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: I forsooth.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: What my most happy wife?

sp.speaker: Merchant wife
sp.p: Why your jealousy?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Jealousy: in faith I do not fear to lose that I have lost already: what are you?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Please your good worship I am a poor gentlewoman, that cast away myself upon an unthrifty captain, that lives now in Ireland, I am fain to pick out a poor living with selling complexion, to keep the frailty (As they say) honest.

sp.speaker: Justi.
sp.p: What's he? complexion to? you are a bawd.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: I thank your good worship for it.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Do not I know these tricks,
That which thou makest a colour for thy sin,
Hath been thy first undoing? painting, painting.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: I have of all sorts forsooth? Here is the burned powder of a hog's jawbone, to be laid with the oil of white poppy, an excellen●●●cus to kill Morphew, weed out freckles, and a most excellent groundwork for painting; here is Ginimony likewise burned, and pulverised, to be mingled with the juice of lemons, sublimate Mercury, and two spoonfuls of the flowers of brimstone, a most excellent receit to cure the flushing in the face.

sp.speaker: Justi.
sp.p:
Do you hear, if you have any business to dispatch with that deaf goodness there, pray you take leave: opportunity, that which most of you long for (Though you never be with child) opportunity? I'll find some idle business in the mean time, I will, I will in truth, you shall not need fear me, or you may speak French, most of your kinds can understand French: god buy you.
Being certain thou art false: sleep, sleep my brain, for doubt was only that, which fed my pain.

sp.speaker: Merchant wife.
sp.p: You see what a hell I live in, I am resolved to leave him.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: O the most fortunate gentlewoman, that will be so wise, and so, so provident, the caroche shall come.

sp.speaker: M. wife.
sp.p: At what hour?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Just when women and vintners are a conjuring at midnight. O the entertainment my lord will make you, sweet wines, lusty diet, perfumed linen, soft beds, oh most fortunate gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Have you done? have you dispatch? 'tis well, and in troth what was the motion?

sp.speaker: M. wife.
sp.p: Motion, what motion?

sp.speaker: Justi.
sp.p: Motion, why like the motion in law, that stays for a day of hearing, yours for a night of hearing. Come let's not have April in your eyes I pray you, it shows a wanton month follows your weeping? Love a woman for her tears? Let a man love oysters for their water, for women though they should weep liquor enough to serve a dyer, or a brewer, yet they may be as stale as wenches, that travail every second tide between graves's end, and Billingsgate.

sp.speaker: Merchant wife.
sp.p: This madness shows very well.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Why look you, I am wondrous merry, can any man discern by my face, that I am a cuckold? I have known many suspected for men of this misfortune; when they have walked thorough the streets, wear their hats o'er their eyebrows, like politic penthouses, which commonly make the shop of a mercer, or a linen draper, as dark as a room in bedlam. His cloak shrouding his face, as if he were a neopolitan that had lost his beard in April, and if he walk through the street, or any other narrow read (As 'tis rate to meet a cuckold) he ducks at the penthouses, like an ancient that dares not flourish at the oath taking of the praetor, for fear of the signposts? Wife, wife, do I any of these? Come what news from his lordship? has not his lordship's virtue once gone against the hair, and coveted corners.

sp.speaker: M. wife.
sp.p: Sir, by my soul I will be plain with you.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Except the forehead dear wife, except the forehead.

sp.speaker: Merchant wife.
sp.p: The gentleman you spoke of hath often solicited my love, and hath received from me most chaste denials.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Ay, ay, provoking resistance, 'tis as if you come to buy wares in the city, bid money fort, your mercer, or goldsmith says, truly I cannot take it, lets his customer pass his stall; next, nay perhaps two, or three, but if he find he is not prone to return of himself, he calls him back, and back, and takes his money: so you my dear wife, (Oh the policy of women, and tradesmen: they'll bite at any thing.)

sp.speaker: M. wife.
sp.p: What would you have me do? all your plate and most part of your jewels are at pawn, besides I hear you have made over all your estate to men in the town here? What would you have me do? would you have me turn common sinner, or sell my apparel to my waistcoat and become a laundress?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: No laundress dear wife, though your credit would go far with gentlemen for taking up of linen: no laundress?

sp.speaker: M. wife.
sp.p: Come, come, I will speak as my misfortune prompts me, jealousy hath undone many a citizen, it hath undone you, and me. You married me from the service of an honourable lady, and you knew what matches I might have had, what would you have me to do? I would I had never seen your eyes, your eyes.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Very good, very good.

sp.speaker: M. wife.
sp.p: Your prodigality, your dicing, your riding abroad, your consorting yourself with noble men, your building a summer house hath undone us, hath undone us? What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Justi.
sp.p: Any thing: I have sold my house, and the wares in't? I am going for stoad next tide, what will you do now wife?

sp.speaker: Merchant wife.
sp.p: Have you indeed?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: I by this light all's one, I have done as some citizens at thirty, and most heirs at three and twenty, made all away, why do you not ask me now what you shall do?

sp.speaker: Merchant wife.
sp.p: I have no counsel in your voyage, neither shall you have any in mine.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: To his lordship: will you not wife?

sp.speaker: Merchant Wif.
sp.p: Even whether my misfortune leads me.

sp.speaker: Justi.
sp.p: Go, no longer will I make my care thy prison.

sp.speaker: M. wife.
sp.p: O my fate; well sir, you shall answer for this sin which you force me to; fare you well, let not the world condemn me, if I seek for mine own maintenance.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: So, so.

sp.speaker: M. wife.
sp.p: Do not send me any letters; do not seek any reconcilement. By this light I'll receive none, if you will send me my apparel so, if not choose, I hope we shall near-meet more.

sp.speaker: Justi.
sp.p: So, farewell the acquaintance of all the mad devils that haunt jealousy, why should a man be such an ass to play the antic for his wife's appetite? Imagine that I, or any other great man have on a velvet nightcap, and put case that this nightcap be too little for my ears or forehead, can any man tell me where my nightcap wrings me, except I be such an ass to proclaim it; well, I do play the fool with my misfortune very handsomely . I am glad that I am certain of my wife's dishonesty; for a secret strumpet, is like mines prepared to ruin goodly buildings. Farewell my care, I have told my wife I am going for stoad; that's not my course, for I resolve to take some shape upon me, and to live disguised here in the city; they say for one cuckold to know that his friend is in the like headache, and to give him counsel, is as if there were two partners, the one to be arrested, the other to bail him: my estate is made over to. My friends, that do verily believe, I mean to leave England. Have amongst you city dames? You that are indeed the fittest, and most proper persons for a comedy, nor let the world lay any imputation upon my disguise, for court, city, and country, are merely as masks one to the other, envied of some, laughed at of others, and so to my comical business.

div.stage: Enter master Tenterhook, his wife, master Monopoly, a scrivener and a cashier.

sp.speaker: Ten.
sp.p: Moll.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: What would heart?

sp.speaker: Tenter.
sp.p: Where's my cashier, are the sums right? Are the bonds sealed?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Yea sir.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Will you have the bags sealed?

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: O no sir, I must disburse instantly ▪ we that be courtiers have more places to send money to, than the devil hath to send his spirits: there's a great deal of light gold.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: O sir, 'twill away in play, and you will stay till tomorrow you shall have it all in new sovereigns.

sp.speaker: Mony.
sp.p: No, introth 'tis no matter, 'twill away in play, let me see the bond? let me see when this money is to be paid? the tenth of August. The first day that I must tender this money, is the first of dog-days.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.p: I fear 'twill be hot staying for you in London then.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Scrivener, take home the bond with you. Will you stay to dinner sir? Have you any partridge Moll?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: No introth heart, but an excellent pickled goose, a new service: pray you stay.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Sooth I cannot: by this light I am so infinitely, so unboundably beholding to you?

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Well signior, I'll leave you; my cloak there?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: When will you come home heart?

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Introth self I know not, a friend of yours and mine hath broke.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Who sir?

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Master Justiniano the Italian.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Broken sir.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Yea sooth, I was offered forty yesterday upon the exchange, to assure a hundred.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: By my troth I am sorry.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: And his wife is gone to the party.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Gone to the party? O wicked creature?

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Farewell good master Monopoly, I prithee visit me often.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Little Moll, send away the fellow?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Phill. Philip.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Here forsooth.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Go into Bucklersbury and fetch me two ounces of preserved melons, look there be no tobacco taken in the shop when he weighs it.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: I forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: What do you eat preserved melons for Moll?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Introth for the shaking of the heart, I have here sometime such a shaking, and downwards such a kind of earthquake (As it were.)

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Do you hear, let your man carry home my money to the ordinary, and lay it in my chamber, but let him not tell my host that it is money: I owe him but forty pound, and the rogue is hasty, he will follow me when he thinks I have money, and pry into me as crow's perch upon carrion, and when he hath found it out, prey upon me as heralds do upon funerals.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Come, come, you owe much money in town: when you have forfeited your bond, I shall ne'er see you more?

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: You are a monkey, I'll pay him for's day: I'll see you tomorrow to.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: By my troth I love you very honestly, you were never the gentleman offered any uncivility to me, which is strange methinks in one that comes from beyond seas, would I had given a thousand pound I could not love thee so.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Do you hear, you shall feign some scurvy disease or other, and go to the bath next spring,Enter mistress Honisuckle, and mistress wafer.I'll meet you there.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: By your leave sweet mistress Tenterhook.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: O, how dost partner?

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Gentlewomen I stayed for a most happy wind, and now the 〈…〉 your sweet, sweet lips, should set me going: good mistress Honisuckle; good mistress wafer, good mistress Tenterhook, I will pray for you, that neither rivalship in loves, pureness of painting, or riding out of town, not acquainting each other withit, be a cause your sweet beauties do fall out, and rail one upon another.

sp.speaker: Wafer.
sp.p: Rail sir, we do not use to rail.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Why mistress, railing is your mother tongue as well as lying.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: But, do you think we can fall out?

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p:
In troth beauties (As one spoke seriously) that there was no inheritance in the amity of princes, so think I of women,
too often interviews amongst women, as amongst princes, breeds envy oft to others fortune, there is only in the amity of women an estate for will, and every puny knows that is no certain inheritance.

sp.speaker: Wafer.
sp.p: You are merry sir.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: So may I leave you most fortunate gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Love shoots hear.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: Tenterhooke, what gentleman is that gone out, is he a man?

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: O God and an excellent trumpeter, he came lately from the university, and love's city dames only for their victuals, he hath an excellent trick to keep lobsters and crabs sweet in summer, and calls it a device to prolong the days of shellfish, for which I do suspect he hath been clerk to some nobleman's kitchen. I have heard he never loves any wench, tell she be as stale as Frenchmen eat their wild foul, I shall anger her.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: How stale good mistress Nimble-wit?

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: Why as stale as a country ostes, an exchange sempster, or a court laundress.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: He is your cousin, how your tongue runs?

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: Talk and make a noise, no matter to what purpose, I have learned that with going to Puritan lectures. I was yesterday at a banquet, will you discharge my ruffs of some wafers, and how doth thy husband wafer?

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: Faith very well.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: He is just like a torch bearer to maskers, he wears good clothes, and is ranked in good company, but he doth nothing: thou art fain to take all, and pay all.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: The more happy she, would I could make such an ass of my husband to. I hear say he breeds thy child in his teeth every year.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: In faith he doth.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: By my troth 'tis pity but the fool should have the other two pains incident to the head.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: Why the headache and horn-ache. I heard say that he would have had thee nursed thy child thyself to.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: That he would truly.

sp.speaker: Honr.
sp.p: Why there's the policy of husbands to keep their wines in. I do assure you if a woman of any markable face in the world give her child suck, look how many wrinkles be in the nipple of her breast, so many will be in her forehead by that time twelvemonth : but sirrah, we are come to acquaint thee with an excellent secret: we two learn to write.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: To write?

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: Yes believe it, and we have the finest school master, a kind of precision, and yet an honest knave to: by my troth if thou beest a good wench let him teach thee, thou mayst send him of any arrant, and trust him with any secret; nay, to see how demurely he will bear himself before our husbands, and how jocund when their backs are turned.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: For god's love let me see him.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: Tomorrow we'll send him to thee: till then sweet Tenterhook we leave thee, wishing thou mayst have the fortune to change thy name often.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: How? change my name?

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: Ay, for thieves and widow's love to shift many names, and make sweet use of it to.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: O you are a wag indeed. Good wafer remember my school master. Farewell good Honysuckle.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: Farewell Tenterhook.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Boniface a prentice brushing his master's cloak and cap. singing
Enter master Honisuckle in his nightcap trussing himself.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: Boniface, make an end of my cloak and Cap.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: I have dispatch 'em sir: both of them lie flat at your mercy.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p:
Fore-god methinks my joints are nimbler every morning
since I came over then they were before. In France when I rise, I was so stiff, and so stark, I would ha' sworn my legs had been wooden pegs: a constable new chosen kept not such a peripatetical gate: but now I'm as limber as an antiant that has flourished in the rain, and as active as a Norfolk tumbler.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: You may see, what change of pasture is able to do.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: It makes fat calves in Rumny marsh, and lean knaves in London: therefore Boniface keep your ground: gods my pity, my forehead has more crumples, than the back part of a counsellors gown, when another rides upon his neck at the bar: Boniface take my helmet: give your mistress my nightcap. Are my antlers swollen so big that my biggin pinches my brows. So, request her to make my head-piece a little wider.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: How much wider sir.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: I can allow her almost an inch: go, tell her so, very near an inch.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: If she be a right citizen's wife, now her husband has given her an inch, she'll take an ell, or a yard at least.

div.stage: Enter signior Justiniano's the merchant, like a writing mechanical pedant.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: Master parenthesis! Salve, salve dominae.

sp.speaker: Justi.
sp.p: Salve tu quoque jubeo te saluere plurimum.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: No more plurimums if you love me, Lattin whole-meates are now minced, and served in for English gallimafries: let us therefore cut out our uplandish neat's tongues, and talk like regenerate Britain's.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Your worship is welcome to England: I poured out orisons for your arrival.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: Thanks good master parenthesis: and que novelles: what news flutters abroad? do jackdaws dung the top of Paul's steeple still.

sp.speaker: Justi.
sp.p: The more is the pity, if any daws do come into the temple, as I fear they do.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p:
They say Charing-cross is fallen down, since I went to Rochelle: but that's no such wonder, 'twas old, and stood awry (As most part of the world can tell.) And though it lack underpropping,
yet (Like great fellows at a wrestling) when their heels are once flying up, no man will save 'em; down they fall, and there let them lie, though they were bigger than the guard: Charing-cross was old, and old things must shrink as well as new Northern cloth.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Your worship is in the right way verily: they must so, but a number of better things between Westminster bridge and temple bar both of a worshipful, and honourable erection, are fallen to decay, and have suffered putrefaction, since Charing fell, that were not of half so long standing as the poor wry-necked monument.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: Who's within there? One of you call up your mistress! tell her here's her writing schoolmaster. I had not thought master parenthesis you had been such an early stirrer.

sp.speaker: Justi.
sp.p: Sir, your vulgar and foure-peny-pen-men, that like your London sempsters keep open shop, and sell learning by retail, may keep their beds, and lie at their pleasure: but we that edify in private, and traffic by whole sale, must be up with the lark, because like country attorneys, we are to shuffle up many matters in a forenoon. Certes master Honisuckle, I would sing laus deo, so I may but please all those that come under my fingers: for it is my duty and function, perdie, to be fervent in my vocation.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Your hand: I am glad our city has so good, so necessary, and so laborious a member in it: we lack painful and expert penmen amongst us. Master parenthesis you teach many of our merchant's sir, do you not?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Both wives, maids, and daughters: and I thank God, the very worst of them lie by very good men's sides: I pick out a poor living amongst 'em, and I am thankful for it.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Trust me I am not sorry: how long have you exercised this quality?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Come Michael-tide next, this thirteen year.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: And how does my wife profit under you sir? hope you to do any any good upon her.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Master Honisuckle I am in great hope she shall fructify: I will do my best for my part: I can do no more than another man can.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: Pray sir ply her, for she is capable of any thing.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: So far as my poor talent can stretch, it shall not be hidden from her.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: Does she hold her pen well yet?

sp.speaker: Justi.
sp.p: She leans somewhat too hard upon her pen yet sir, but practise and animadversion will break her from that.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: Then she grubs her pen.

sp.speaker: Justi.
sp.p: It's but my pains to mend the neb again.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: And whereabouts is she now master parenthesis? She was talking of you this morning, and commending you in her bed, and told me she was passed her letters.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Truly sir she took her letters very suddenly: and is now in her minoms.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: I would she were in her crotchets too master parenthesis: haha, I must talk merrily sir.

sp.speaker: Justi.
sp.p: Sir so long as your mirth be void of all scurility, 'tis not unfit for your calling: I trust ere few days be at an end to have her fall to her joining: for she has her letters and unguem: her a. her great B. and her great C. very right D. and E. delicate: her double F. of a good length, but that it straddles a little to wide: at the G. very cunning.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: Her H. is full like mine: a goodly big H.

sp.speaker: Justi.
sp.p: But her: double ll is well: her o. of a reasonable size: at her p. and q. neither merchant's daughter, alderman's wife, young country gentlewoman, nor courtier's mistress, can match her.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: And how herv.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: You sir, she fetches up you best of all: her single you she can fashion two or three ways: but her double you, is as I would wish it.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: And faith who takes it faster; my wife, or mistress Tenterhook?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Oh! your wife by odds: she'll take more in one hour, than I can fasten either upon mistress Tenterhook, or mistress wafer, or mistress flap-dragon (The brewer's wife) in three.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: Do not thy cheeks burn sweet chuckaby, for we are talking of thee.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: No goodness I warrant: you have few citizens speak well of their wives behind their backs: but to their faces they'll cog worse and be more suppliant, than clients that sue in forma paper: how does my master? troth I am a very truant: have you your ruler about you master? for look you, I go clean awry.

sp.speaker: Justi.
sp.p:
A small fault: most of my scholars do so: look you
sir, do not you think your wife will mend: mark her dashes, and her strokes, and her breakings, and her bendings?

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: She knows what I have promised her if she do mend: say by my fay Jude, this is well, if you would not fly out thus, but keep your line.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: I shall in time when my hand is in: have you a new pen for me master, for by my truly, my old one is stark naught, and will cast no ink: whither are you going lamb?

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: To the customhouse: to the change, to my warehouse, to divers places.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Good coal tarry not passed eleven, for you turn my stomach then from my dinner.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: I will make more haste home, than a stipendiary Swisser does after he's paid, fare you well master parenthesis.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: I am so troubled with the rheum too: mouse what's good fort?

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: How often have I told you, you must get a patch. I must hence.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: I think when all's done I must follow his counsel, and take a patch, I have had one long ere this, but for disfiguring my face: yet I had noted that a mastic patch upon some women's temples, hath been the very rheum of beauty.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Is he departed? Is old Nestor marched into Troy?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Yes you mad Greek: the gentleman's gone.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Why then clap up coppy-books: down with pens, hang up inkhorns, and now my sweet Honisuckle, see what golden-winged bee from Hybla, flies humming, with crura thymo plena, which he will empty in the hive of your bosom.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: From whom.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p:
At the skirt of that sheet in black work is wrought his name, break not up the wildfowl, till anon, and then feed upon him in private: there's other irons i'th fire: more sacks are coming to the mill, oh you sweet temptations of the sons of Adam, I commend you, extol you, magnify you: were I a poet by Hipocrene I swear, (Which was a certain well where all the Muses watered) and by Parnassus eke I swear, I would ●ime you to death with praises, for that you can be content to lie with old men all night for their money, and walk to your gardens with young men i'th day time for your pleasure: o you delicate damnations:
you do but as I would do: were I the properest, sweetest, plumpest, cherry-cheeked, coral-lipped woman in a kingdom, I would not dance after one man's pipe.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: And why?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Especially after an old man's.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: And why, pray!

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Especially after an old citizens.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Still, and why.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Marry because the suburbs, and those without the bars, have more privilege than they within the freedom: what need one woman do ate upon one man? Or one man be mad like Orlando for one woman.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Troth 'tis true, considering how much flesh is in every shambles.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Why should I long to eat of baker's bread only, when there's so much sifting, and bolting, and grinding in every corner of the city; men and women are born, and come running into the world faster than coaches do into Cheapside upon Simon and Jude's day: and are eaten up by death faster, than mutton and porridge in a term time. Who would pin their hearts to any sleeve: this world is like a mint, we are no sooner cast into the fire, taken out again, hammered, stamped, and made currant, but presently we are changed: the new money (Like a new drab) is caught at by Dutch, Spanish, Welsh, French, Scotch, and English: but the old cracked King Harry groats are shovelled up, feel bruising, and battering, clipping, and melting, they smoke sort.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: The worlds an arrant naughty-pack I see, and is a very scurvy world.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Scurvy? worse than the conscience of a broomeman, that carries out new ware, and brings home old shoes: a naughty-pack? Why there's no minute, no thought of time passes, but some villainy or other is a brewing: why, even now, now, at holding up of this finger, and before the turning down of this, some are murdering, some lying with their maids, some picking of pockets, some cutting purses, some cheating, some weighing out bribes. In this city some wives are cuckolding some husbands. In yonder village some farmers are now-now grinding the jaw-bones of the poor: therefore sweet scholar, sugared mistress Honisuckle, take summer before you, and lay hold of it? why, even now must you and I hatch an egg of iniquity.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Troth master I think thou wilt prove a very knave.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: It's the fault of many that fight under this band.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: I shall love a Puritans face the worse whilst I live for that copy of thy countenance.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: We are all weathercocks, and must follow the wind of the present: from the bias.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Change a bowl then.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: I will so; and now for a good cast: there's the knight, sir Goson glow-worm.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: He's a knight made out of wax.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: He took up silks upon his bond I confess: nay more, he's a knight in print: but let his knighthood be of what stamp it will, from him come I, to entreat you, and mistress wafer, and mistress Tenterhook, being both my scholars, and your honest pew fellows, to meet him this afternoon at the rhenish-wine-house ith' stillyard. Captain whirlpool will be there, young Linstock the alderman's son and heir, there too, will you steal forth, and taste of a Dutch bun, and a keg of sturgeon.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: What excuse shall I coin now?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Few excuses: you must to the pawn to buy lawn: to saint Martin's for lace; to the garden: to the glass-house; to your gossips: to the poulters: else take out an old ruff, and go to your sempsters: excuses? Why, they are more ripe than meddlers at Christmas.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: I'll come. The hour.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Two: the way-through Paul's: every wench take a pillar, there clap on your masks: your men will be behind you, and before your prayers be half done, be before you, and man you out at several doors. You'll be there?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: If I breathe.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Farewell. So: now must I go set the tother wenches the self same copy. A rare schoolmaster, for all kind of hands, I. O: what strange curses are poured down with one blessing? Do all tread on the heel? Have all the art to hoodwink wise men thus? And (Like those bvilders of Babel's tower) to speak unknown tongues. Of all (Save by their husbands) understood: well, if (As ivy bout the elm does twine)
sp.l: All wives love clipping, there's no fault in mine.
But if the world lay speechless, even the dead
Would rise, and thus cry out from yawning graves,
Women make men, or fools, or beasts, or slaves.

div.head: Scaena 2.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Her answer! talk in music: will she come?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: O my sides ache in my loins, in my bones? I ha' more need of a posset of sack, and lie in my bed and sweat, than to talk in music: no honest woman would run hurrying up and down thus and undo herself for a man of honour, without reason? I am so lame, every foot that I set to the ground went to my heart. I thought I had been at mumchance my bones rattled so with jaunting? had it not been for a friend in a corner. Takes aquavitae.I had kicked up my heels.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Minister comfort to me, will she come.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: All the castles of comfort that I can put you into is this, that the jealous wittol her husband, came (Like a mad ox) bellowing in whilst I was there. O I ha' lost my sweet breath with trotting.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Death to my heart? her husband? What saith he?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: The freeze-jerkin rascal out with his purse, and called me plain bawd to my face.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Affliction to me, then thou spak'st not to her?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: I spoke to her, as clients do to lawyers without money (To no purpose) but I'll speak with him, and hamper him to, if ever he fall into my clutches: I'll make the yellow-hammer her husband know, (For all he's an italian) that there's a difference between a cogging bawd and an honest motherly gentlewoman. Now, what cold whetstones lie over your stomacher? will you have some of my aqua? Why my lord.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Thou hast killed me with thy words.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: I see bashful lovers and young bullocks are knocked down at a blow: come, come ▪ drink this draught of cinnamon water, and pluck up your spirits: up with 'em, up with 'em. Do you hear, the whiting mop has nibbled.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p:
O? I thought I should fetch you: you can ha at that: I'll make you hem anon. As I'm a sinner I think you'll find the sweetest,
sweetest bedfellow of her. Oh! she looks so sugaredly, so simperingly, so gingerly, so amorously, so amiably. Such a red lip, such a white forehead, such a black eye, such a full cheek, and such a goodly little nose, now she's in that French gown, Scotch falls, Scotch bum, and Italian head-tire you sent her, and is such an enticing she-witch, carrying the charms of your jewels about her. O●●!

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Did she receive them? speak: here's is golden keys t'unlock thy lips. Did she vouchsafe to take them?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Did she vouchsafe to take them, there's a question: you shall find she did vouchsafe: the troth is my lord, I got her to my house, there she put off her own clothes my lord and put on yours my lord, provided her a coach, searched the middle I'll in Pawles, and with three Elizabeth twelvepences pressed three knaves my l. hired three liveries in Long-lane, to man her: for all which so God mend me, I'm to pay this night before sunset.

sp.speaker: Earl,
sp.p: This shower shall fill them all rain in their laps, what golden drops thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Alas my lord, I do but receive it with one hand, to pay it away with another, I'm but your baily.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Where is she?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: In the green velvet chamber; the poor sinful creature pants like a pigeon under the hands of a hawk, therefore use her like a woman my lord: use her honestly my lord, for alas she's but a novice, and a very green thing.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Farewell: I'll in unto her.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Fie upon't, that were not for your honour: you know gentlewomen use to come to lords chambers, and not lords to the gentlewomen's; I'd not have her think you are such a rank-rider: walk you here: I'll beckon, you shall see I'll fetch her with a wet finger?

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Do so.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p:
Hyst? why sweet heart, mistress Justiniano's, why pretty soul tread softly, and come into this room: here be rushes, you need not fear the creaking of your cork shoes. Enter mistress Justiniano's.so, well said, there's his honour. I have business my lord, very now
the marks are set up: I'll get me 〈◊〉 score off, and give aim.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: You're welcome: sweet you're welcome. Bless my hand
With the soft touch of yours: can you be cruel
To one so prostrate to you? Even my heart,
My happiness, and state lie at your feet:
My hopes me flattered that the field was won,
That you had yielded, (Though you conquer me)
And that all marble scales that barred your eyes
From throwing light on mine, were quite ta'en off,
By the cunning woman's hand, that works for me,
Why therefore do you wound me now with frowns?
Why do you fly me? Do not exercise
The art of woman on me? I'm already
Your captive: sweet! Are these your hate, or ●eares.

sp.speaker: Mistress Iust.
sp.l: I wonder lust can hang at such white hairs.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: You give my love ill names, it is not lust:
Lawless desires well tempered may seem just
sp.p: A thousand mornings with the early sun, mine eyes have from your windows watched to steal brightness from those. As oft upon the days that consecrated to devotion are, within the holy temple have I stood disguised, waiting your presence: and when your hands went up towards heaven to draw some blessing down, mine (As if all my nerves by yours did move,)
sp.l: Begged in dumb signs some pity for my love,
And thus being feasted only with your fight,
I went more pleased than sickmen with fresh health,
Rich men with honour, beggars do with wealth.

sp.speaker: Mistress Iust.
sp.l: Part now so pleased, for now you more enjoy me.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: O you do wish me physic to destroy me.

sp.speaker: Mrs., Iust.
sp.p: I have already leapt beyond the bounds of modesty, in piecing out my wings with borrowed feathers: but you sent a sorceress so perfect in her trade, that did so lively breath forth your passionate accents, and could draw a lover languishing so piercingly, that her charms wrought upon me, and in pity of your sick heart which she did counterfeit, (O she's a subtle beldame!) See I clothed my limbs (Thus player-like in rich attires, not fitting mine estate, and am come forth, but why I know not?

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Will you love me?

sp.speaker: Mistress Iust.
sp.l: Yes,
If you can clear me of a debt that's due but to one man,
I'll pay my heart to thee.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Mistress Iust.
sp.l: My husband.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: Umh.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iust.
sp.l: The sums so great
I know a kingdom cannot answer it,
And therefore I beseech you good my lord,
To take this gilding off, which is your own,
And henceforth cease to throw out golden hooks
To choke mine honour: though my husband's poor,
I'll rather beg for him, then be your whore.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: 'Gainst beauty you plot treason, if you suffer tears to do violence to so fair a cheek. That face was ne'er made to look pale with want. Dwell here and be the sovereign of my fortunes. Thus shall you go attired.

sp.speaker: Mistress Iust.
sp.p: Till lust be tired. I must take leave my lord.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: Sweet creature stay,
My coffers shall be yours, my servants yours,
sp.p: Myself will be your servant, and I swear by that which I hold dear in you, your beauty (And which I'll not profane) you shall live here as free from base wrong, as you are from blackness, so you will deign, but let me enjoy your sight, answer me will you.

sp.speaker: Mistress Iust.
sp.p: I will think upon't.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Unless you shall perceive, that all my thoughts, and all my actions be to you devoted, and that I very justly earn your love, let me not taste it.

sp.speaker: Mistress Iust.
sp.p: I will think upon it.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: But when you find my merits of full weight, will you accept their worth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iust.
sp.l: I'll think upon't.
I'd speak with the old woman.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: She shall come,
Joys that are born unlooked for, are born dumb.

sp.speaker: Mistress Iust.
sp.l: Poverty, thou bane of chastity,
Poison of beauty, broker of maidenheads,
sp.p:
I see when force, nor wit can scale the hold, wealth must. She'll
never be won, that defies gold.
sp.l: But lives there such a creature: o 'tis rare.
To find a woman chaste, that's poor and fair.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Now lamb! has not his honour dealt like an honest nobleman with you. I can tell you. you shall not find him a templar, nor one of these cogging Cattern pear-coloured-beards, that by their good 〈◊〉 would have no pretty woman scape them.

sp.speaker: Mistress. Iust.
sp.l: Thou art a very bawd: thou art a devil
Cast in a reverend shape; thou stale damnation!
Why hast thou me enticed from mine own paradise,
To steal fruit in a barren wilderness.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Bawd and devil, and stale damnation! Will women's tongues (Like bakers legs) never go straight.

sp.speaker: Mistress. Iust.
sp.l: Had thy Circaean magic me transformed
Into that sensual shape for which thou conjur'st,
And that I were turned common venturer,
I could not love this old man.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: This old man, umh: this old man? do his hoary hairs stick in your stomach? yet methinks his silver hairs should move you, they may serve to make you bodkins: does his age grieve you? fool? Is not old wine wholesomest, old pippins toothsommest, old wood burn brightest, old linen wash whitest, old soldier's sweetheart are surest, and old lovers are soundest. I hatried both.

sp.speaker: Mistress. Iust.
sp.p: So will not I.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: You'd have some young perfumed beardless gallants board you, that spits all his brains out at's tongues end, would you not?

sp.speaker: Mistress. Iust.
sp.p: No, none at all, not any.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: None at all? what do you make there then? why are you a burden to the world's conscience, and an eyesore to well given men, I dare pawn my gown and all the beds in my house, and all the gettings in Michaelmas term next to a tavern token, that thou shalt never be an innocent.

sp.speaker: Mistress. Iust.
sp.p: Who are so?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p:
Fool's? why then are you so precise: your husbands down the wind and will you like a hagglers arrow, be down the weather, strike whilst the iron is hot. A woman when there be roses in her
cheeks, cherries on her lips, civet in her breath, ivory in her teeth, lilies in her hand, and liquorish in her heart, why she's like a play. If new very good company, very good company, but if stale, like old Jeronimo: go by, go by. Therefore as I said before, strike. Besides: you must think that the commodity of beauty was not made to lie dead upon any young woman's hands: if your husband have given up his cloak, let another take measure of you in his jerkin: for as the cobbler, in the night time walks with his lantern, the merchant, and the lawyer with his link, and the courtier with his torch: so every lip has his lettuce to himself: the lob has his lass, the collier his dowdy, the western - man his pug, the servingman his punk, the student his nun in white friars, the Puritan his sister, and the lord his lady: which worshipful vocation may fall upon you, if you'll but strike whilst the iron is hot.

sp.speaker: Mistress Iust.
sp.p: Witch: thus I break thy spells: were I kept brave, on a King's cost, I am but a King's slave.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: I see, that as Frenchmen love to be bold, Flemings to be drunk, Welshmen to be called Brittons, and Irishmen to be costermongers, so, cocknyes, (Especially shee-cocknies) love not aquavite when tis-good for them.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Saw you my uncle?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: I saw him even now going the way of all flesh (That's to say) towards the kitchen: here's a letter to your worship from the party.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: What party?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: The Tenterbook your wanton.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: From her? Fewh? pray thee stretch me no more upon your Tenterhook: pox on her? Are there no pothecaries ith' town to send her physic-bills to, but me: she's not troubled with the green sickness still, is she?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: The yellow jaundice , as the doctor tells me: troth she's as good a peat: she is fallen away so, that she's nothing but bare skin and bone: for the turtle so mourns for you.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: In black?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: In black? you shall find both black and blue if you look under her eyes.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Well: sing over her ditty when I'm in tune,

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p:
Nay, but will you send her a box of mithridatum and dragon water, I mean some restorative words. Good master Monopoly
you know how welcome you're to the city, and will you master Monopoly, keep out of the city; I know you cannot, would you saw how the poor gentlewoman lies.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Why how lies she?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Troth as the way lies over Gadshill, very dangerous: you would pity a woman's case if you saw her: write to her some treatise of pacification.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: I'll write to her tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Tomorrow; she'll not sleep then but tumble, and if she might have it tonight , it would better please her.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Perhaps I'll do't tonight , farewell.

sp.speaker: Bi.
sp.p: If you do't tonight , it would better please her then tomorrow .

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: God's so, dost hear, I'm to sup this night at the lion in Shoreditch with certain gallants: canst thou not draw forth some delicate face, that I ha' not seen, and bring it thither, wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: All the painters in London shall not fit for colour as I can; but we shall have some swaggering?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: All as civil (By this sight) as lawyers.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: But I tell you, she's not so common as lawyers, that I mean to betray to your table: for as I'm a sinner, she's a knight's cousin; a Yorkshire gentlewoman, and only speaks a little broad, but of very good carriage.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Nay that's no matter, we can speak as broad as she? but wilt bring her?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: You shall call her cousin, do you see: two men shall wait upon her, and I'll come in by chance: but shall not the party be there?

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Which party?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: The writer of that simple hand.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Not for as many angels as there be letters in her paper: speak not of me to her, nor our meeting if you love me: wilt come?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Mum, I'll come.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Good master Monopoly, I hope to see you one day a man of great credit.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: If I be, I'll build chimneys with tobacco but I'll smoke some: and be sure bird. I'll stick wool upon thy back.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Thanks sir, I know you will, for all the kindred of the monopolies are held to be great fleecers.

div.stage: Enter sir Gozlin: Lynstocke, whirlpool, and the three citizens' wives masked, Judith, Mabell, and Clare.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: So draw those curtains; and let's see the pictures under 'em.

sp.speaker: Lyn.
sp.p: Welcome to the stillyard fair ladies.

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.p: Thanks good master Linstock.

sp.speaker: Whirl.
sp.p: Hans: some wine Hans.

div.stage: Enter Hans with cloth and buns.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.l: Yaw, yaw, you sall hebben it mester:
Old vine, or new vine?

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: Speak women.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: New wine good sir Gozlin: wine in the must, good Dutchman, for must is best for us women.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: New vine? vell: two pots of new vine.

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.p: An honest butterbox: for if it be old, there's none of it coms into my belly.

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: Why Tenterhook pray thee let's dance friskin, and be merry.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Thou art so troubled with monopolies, they so hang at thy heart strings.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Pox a my heart then.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: I and mine too, if any courtier of them all set up his gallows there: wench use him as thou dost thy pantables, scorn to let him kiss thy heel, for he feeds thee with nothing but court holy bread, good words, and cares not for thee: sir Gozlin, will you taste a Dutch whatch you call 'em.

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: Here master Linstock, half mine is yours. Bun, Bun, Bun, Bun.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Which room? where are they? wo ho, ho, ho, so, ho boys.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: 'Sfoot who's that? lock our room.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Not till I am in: and then lock out the devil though he come in the shape of a Puritan.

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.p: Schoolmaster, welcome? welcome in troth?

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Who would not be scratched with the briers and brambles to have such burrs sticking on his breeches: save you gentlemen: oh noble knight.

sp.speaker: Goz
sp.p: More wine Hans.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Am not I (Gentlemen) a ferret of the right hair, that can make three coneys bolt at a clap into your pursenets? ha? little do their 3. husband's dream what copies I am setting their wives now? wert not a rare jest if they should come sneaking upon us like a horrible noise of fiddlers.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Troth I'd not care: let 'em come: I'd tell 'em, weed h● none of their dull music.

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: Here mistress Tenterhook.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Thanks good mistress wafer.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Who's there? Peepers: intelligencers: evesdroppers.

sp.speaker: Omni.
sp.p: Uds foot, throw a pot at's head?

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: O lord? O gentlemen, knight, ladies, that may be, citizens wives that are, shift for yourselves, for a pair of your husband's heads are knocking together with Hans his, and enquiring for you. Omni. Keep the door locked.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: O ay, do, do: and let sir Gozlin (Because he has been in the low countries) swear God's sacrament, and drive 'em away with broken Dutch.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Here's a wench has simple sparks in her: she's my pupil gallants: good-god? I see a man is not sure that his wife is in the chamber, though his own fingers hung on the padlock: trapdoors, false drabs, and spring-locks, may cozen a co●y of constables. How the silly husbands might here ha' been gulled with Flemish money: come: drink up Rhine, Thames and Meander dry, there's nobody.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Ah thou ungodly master.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: I did but make a false fire, to try your valour, because you cried let 'em come. By this glass of woman's wine, I would not ha' seen their spirits walk here, to be dubbed deputy of a ward, ay, they would ha' chronicled me for a fox in a lamb's skin: but come: is this merry midsummer night agreed upon? when shall it be? where shall it be?

sp.speaker: Lynst.
sp.p: Why faith tomorrow at night.

sp.speaker: Whirle.
sp.p: We'll take a coach and ride to ham, or so.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: O fie upon't: a coach? I cannot abide to be jolted.

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: Yet most of your citizen's wives love jolting?

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: What say you to black-wall, or limehouse?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Every room there smells to much of tar.

sp.speaker: Lynst.
sp.p: Let's to mine host Aun at Brainford then, there you are out of eyes, out of ears ▪ private rooms, sweet linen, winking attendance, and what cheer you will?

sp.speaker: Omni.
sp.p: Content, to Bramford?

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let's go by water, for sir Gozlin I have heard you say you love to go by water.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: But wenches, with what pulleys shall we slide with some cleanly excuse, out of our husband's suspicion, being gone westward for smelts all night.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: That's the block now we all stumble at: wind up that ●●ring well, and all the consorts in tune.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Why then goodman scraper 'tis wound up, I have it. Sirrah wafer, thy child's at nurse, if you that are the men could provide some wise ass that could keep his countenance.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Nay if he be an ass he will keep his countenance.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Ay, but I mean, one that could set out his tale with audacity, and say that the child were sick, and near stagger at it: that last should serve all our feet.

sp.speaker: Whir.
sp.p: But where will that wise ass be found now?

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: I see I'm born still to draw Dun out ath' mire for you: that wise beast will I be. I'll be that ass that shall groan under the burden of that abominable lie. Heaven pardon me, and pray God the infant be not punished fort. Let me see: I'll break out in some filthy shape like a thrasher, or a thatcher, or a sowgelder, or something: and speak dreamingly, and swear how the child pukes, and eats nothing (As perhaps it does not) and lies at the mercy of God, (As all children and oldefolkes do) and then scholar wafer, play you your part.

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: Fear not me, for a veny or two?

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Where will you meet ith' morning?

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: At some tavern near the waterside, that's private.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: The greyhound, the greyhound in Blackfriars, an excellent rendezvous.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Content the greyhound by eight?

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: And than you may whip forth two first, and two next, on a sudden, and take boat at Bridewell dock most privately.

sp.speaker: Omni.
sp.p: Beet so: a good place?

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: I'll go make ready my rustical properties: let me see scholar hie you home, for your child shall be sick within this half hour.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: 'Tis the uprightest dealing man? God's my pity, whose yonder?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: I'm bold to press myself under the colours of of your company, hearing that gentlewoman was in the room: a word mistress?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: How now, what says he?

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: Zounds what she? A bawd, byth' lord is't not?

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: No indeed, sir Gozlin she's a very honest woman, and a mid-wife.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: At the lion in Shoreditch? And would he not read it? nor write to me? I'll poison his supper?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: But no words that I bewrayed him.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Gentlemen I must be gone. I cannot stay in faith: pardon me: I'll meet tomorrow: come nurse, cannot tarry by this element.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: Mother, you: grannam drink ere you go. Bird: I am going to a woman's labour, indeed sir, cannot stay.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: I hold my life the black-beard her husband whistles for her.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: A reckoning: break one, break all.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: Here Hans, draw not, I'll draw for all as I'm true knight.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Let him: amongst women this does stand for law, the worthiest man (Though he be fool) must draw.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter master Tenterhooke and his wife.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: What book is that sweet heart?

sp.speaker: Mistress Ten.
sp.p: Why the book of bonds that are due to you.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Come, what do you with it? Why do you trouble yourself to take care about my business?

sp.speaker: Mistress Ten.
sp.p: Why sir, doth not that which concerns you, concern me. You told me monopoly had discharged his bond, I find by the book of accounts here, that it is not cancelled. Ear I would suffer such a cheating companion to laugh at me, I'd see him hanged I ▪ good sweet heart as ever you loved me, as ever my bed was pleasing to you, arrest the knave, we were never beholding to him for a pin, but for eating up our victuals. Good mouse enter an action against him.

sp.speaker: Ten.
sp.p: In troth love I may do the gentleman much discredit, and besides it may be other actions may fall very heavy upon him.

sp.speaker: Mistress Tent.
sp.p: Hang him, to see the dishonesty of the knave.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: O wise, good words: a courtier, a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mistress Tent.
sp.p: Why may not a gentleman be a knave, that were strange in faith: but as I was a saying, to see the dishonesty of him, that would never come since he received the money to visit us you know. Master Tenterhook he hath hung long upon you. Master Tenterhook as I am virtuous you shall arrest him.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Why, I know not when he will come to town.

sp.speaker: Mistress Te.
sp.p: He's in town: this night he sups at the lion in Shoreditch, good husband enter your action, and make haste to the lion presently, there's an honest fellow (Sergeant ambush) will do it in a trice, he never salutes a man in courtesy, but he catches him as if he would arrest him. Good heart let sergeant ambush lie in wait for him.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p:
Well at thy entreaty I will do it. Give me my cloak
there, buy a link and meet me at the counter in Woodstreet; buss me Moll.

sp.speaker: Mistress Tent.
sp.p: Why now you love me. I'll go to bed sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Tent:
sp.p: Do not sleep till I come Moll.

sp.speaker: Mistress Tent:
sp.p: No lamb, baa sheep, if a woman will be free in this intricate labyrinth of a husband, let her marry a man of a melancholy complexion, she shall not be much troubled with him. By my sooth my husband hath a hand as dry as his brains, and a breath as strong as six common gardens. Well my husband is gone to arrest monopoly. I have dealt with a sergeant priuatly, to entreat him, pretending that he is my aunt's son, by this means shall I see my young gallant that in this has played his part. When they owe money in the city once, they deal with their lawyers by attorney, follow the court though the court do them not the grace to allow them their dyer. O the wit of a woman when she is put to the pinch.

div.stage: Enter master Tenterhook, sergeant ambush, and yeoman Clutch.

sp.speaker: Ten.
sp.p: Come sergeant ambush, come yeoman clutch, yond's the tavern ▪ the gentleman will come out presently: thou art resolute.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Who I, I carry fire and sword that fight for me, hear, and hear. I know most of the knaves about London, and most of the thieves to, I thank God ▪ and good intelligence.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: I wonder thou dost not turn broker then.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Pew; I have been a broker already; for I was first a Puritan, than a bankrupt, than a broker, than a fencer, and then sergeant, were not these trades would make a man honest? peace the door opens, wheel about yeoman clutch.

div.stage: Enter whirlpool, Linstocke, and monopoly unbraced.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: And ere I come to sup in this tavern again. There's no more attendance than in a jail, and there had been a punk or two in the company than we should not have been rid of the drawers: now were I in an excellent humour to go to a valting house ▪ I would break down all their glass-windows, hew in pieces all their join stools, tear silk petticoats, ruffle their periwigs, and spoil their painting, oh the gods what I could do: I could undergo fifteen bawds by this darkness, or if I could meet one of these varlets that were pannier ally on their backs (Sergeants) I would make them scud so fast from me, that they should think it a shorter way between this and Ludgate, than a condemned cutpurse thinks it between Newgate and Tyburn.

sp.speaker: Lynst.
sp.p: You are for no action tonight .

sp.speaker: Whirl.
sp.p: No I'll to bed.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Am not I drunk now: implentur veteris bacchi, pi●quisque tobacco.

sp.speaker: Whirle.
sp.p: Faith we are all heated.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Captain whirlpool when wilt come to court and dine with me?

sp.speaker: Whirl.
sp.p: One of these days Frank, but I'll get me two gauntlets for fear I lose my fingers in the dishes, their be excellent shavers I hear in the most of your under offices? I protest I have often come thither, sat down drawn, my knife, and ear I could say grace all the meat hath been gone. I have risen, and departed thence as hungry, as ever came country attorney from Westminster? Good night honest Frank, do not swagger with the watch Frank.

sp.speaker: Tenter.
sp.p: So now they are gone you may take him.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Sir I arrest you?

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Arrest me, at whose suit you varlets?

sp.speaker: Clouch.
sp.p: At master tenterhooks.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Why you varlets dare you arrest one of the court.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Come will you be quiet sir?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Pray thee good yeoman call the gentlemen back again. There's a gentleman hath carried a hundred pound of mine home with him to his lodging, because I dare not carry it over the fields, I'll discharge it presently.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: That's a trick sir, you would procure a rescue.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Catchpole do you see, I will have the hair of your head and beard shaved off for this, and ear I catch you at Gray's inn by this light law.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Come will you march.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Are you sergeants Christians? Sirrah thou lookest like a good pitiful rascal, and thou art a tall man to it seems, thou hast backed many a man in thy time I warrant.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: I have had many a man by the back sir.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p:
Well-said introth, I love your quality, 'las 'tis needful every man should come by his own ▪ but as God mend me gentlemen I have not one cross about me, only you two. Might not you let a gentlemen pass out of your hands, and say you saw him not? Is there not such a kind of mercy in you now and then my masters, as I live, if you come to my lodging to morrow morning, I'll give you five brace of angels? good yeoman persuade your
graduate here: I know some of you to be honest faithful drunkards, respect a poor gentleman in my case.

sp.speaker: Ten
sp.p: Come, it will not serve your turn, officers look to him, upon your peril.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Do you hear sir, you see I am in the hands of a couple of ravens here, as you are a gentleman lend me forty shillings, let me not live if I do not pay you the forfeiture of the whole bond, and never plead conscience.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Not a penny, not a penny: God night sir.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Well, a man ought not to sweat by any thing in the hands of sergeants but by silver, and because my pocket is no lawful justice to minister any such oath unto me, I will patiently encounter the counter. Which is the dearest ward in prison sergeant! the knight's ward?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: No sir, the master's side.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Well the knight is above the master though his table be worse furnished: I'll go thither.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Come sir, I must use you kindly the gentleman's wife that hath arrested you.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: I what of her.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: She says you are her aunt's son.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Ay, am?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: She takes on so pitifully for your arresting, 'twas much against her will (Good gentlewoman) that this affliction lighted upon you.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: She hath reason, if she respect her poor kindred.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: You shall not go to prison.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Honest sergeant, conscionable officer, did I forget myself even now, a vice that sticks to me always when I am drunk to abuse my best friends: where didst buy this buff? Let me not live but I'll give thee a good suit of durance, wilt thou take my bond sergeant? Where's a scrivener, a scrivener good yeoman? you shall have my sword and hangers to pay him.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Not so sir: but you shall be prisoner in my house: I do not think but that your cousin will visit you there i'th morning, and take order for you.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Well said; wast not a most treacherous part to arrest a man in the night ▪ and when he is almost drunk, when he hath not his wits about him to remember which of his friends is in the subsidy: come did I abuse you, I recant, you are as necessary in a city as tumblers in Norfolk, sumners in Lancashire, or rakehells in an army ▪

div.stage: Enter parenthesis like a collier, and a boy.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Buy any small coal, buy any small coal.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Collier, collier?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: What sayest boy.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Ware the pillory.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: O boy the pillory assures many a man that he is no cuckold, for how impossible wear it a man should thrust his head through so small a loophole if his forehead were branched boy?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Collier: how came the goose to be put upon you, ha?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: I'll tell thee, the term lying at Winchester in Henry the thirds days, and many French women coming out of the isle of wight thither (As it hath always been seen) though the isle of wight could not of long time neither endure foxes nor lawyers. yet it could brook the more dreadful cockatrice, there were many punks in the town (As you know our term is their term) your farmers that would spend but three pence on his ordinary, would lavish half a crown on his lechery: and many men (Calves as they were) would ride in a farmer's foul boots before breakfast, the commonest sinner had more fluttering about her, than a fresh punk hath when she comes to a town of garrison, or to a university. Captains, scholars, serving-men, jurors, clarks, townsmen, and the blackguard used all to one ordinary, and most of them were called to a pitiful reckoning ▪ for before two returns of Michaelmas, surgeons were full of business, the care of most secrecy grew as common as lice in Ireland, or as scabs in France. One of my tribe a collier carried in his cart 40. maimed soldiers to Salisbury, looking as pitifully as Dutchmen first made drunk, then carried to beheading. Every one that met him cried, beware the goose collier, and from that day to this, there's a record to be seen at Croyden, how that pitiful wa●tage which in deed was virtue in the collier, that all that time would carry no coals, laid this imputation on all the posterity.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: You are full of tricks collier.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Boy where dwells master wafer?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why hear! what wouldst? I am one of his iuvinals?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Hath he not a child at nurse at More-clack?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, dost thou dwell there?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p:
That I do, the child is wondrous sick: I was wild to acquaint
thy master and mistress with it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I'll up and tell them presently.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: So, if all should fail me, I could turn collier. O the villainy of this age, how full of secrecy and silence (Contrary to the opinion of the world) have I ever found most women. I have sat a whole afternoon many times by my wife, and looked upon her eyes, and felt if her pulses have beat, when I have named a suspected love, yet all this while have not drawn from her the least scruple of confession. I have lain awake a thousand nights, thinking she would have revealed somewhat in her dreams, and when she has begun to speak any thing in her sleep, I have jogged her, and cried I sweet heart. But when will your love come, or what did he say to thee over the stall? Or what did he do to thee in the garden-chamber? Or when will he send to thee any letters, or when wilt thou send to him any money, what an idle coxcomb jealousy will make a man. Enter wafer and his wife.well, this is my comfort that here comes a creature of the same head-piece.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Waf.
sp.p: O my sweet child, where's the collier?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Here forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Waf.
sp.p: Run into bucklers burry for two ounces of dragon water, so●e sperma 〈◊〉 and treacle. What is it sick of coliar? ● burning fever?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Faith mistress I do not know the infirmity of it: will you buy any small coal, say you?

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: Prithee go in and empty them, come be not so impatient.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Waf.
sp.p: Ay, ay, ay, if you had groaned fort as I have done you would have been more natural. Take my riding hat, and my kirtle there: I'll away presently?

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: You will not go tonight , I am sure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. wafer.
sp.p: As I live but I will.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: Faith sweet heart I have great business tonight , stay till tomorrow and I'll go with you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Waf.
sp.p: No sir I will not hinder your business. I see how little you respect the fruits of your own body. I shall find somebody to bear me company.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: Well, I will defer my business for once, and go with thee.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Waf.
sp.p: By this light but you shall not, you shall not hit me i'th teeth that I was your hindrance, will you to bucklers burry sir?

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: Come you are a fool leave your weeping.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Waf.
sp.p: You shall not go with me as I live.

sp.speaker: Iust ▪
sp.p: Puple.

sp.speaker: Mistress Waf.
sp.p: Excellent master.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Admirable mistress, how happy be our Englishwomen that are not troubled with jealous husbands; why your Italians in general are so sunburnt with these dog-days, that your great lady there thinks her husband loves her not if he be not jealous: what confirms the liberty of our women more in England, than the Italian proverb, which says if there were a bridge over the narrow seas, all the women in Italy would show their husbands a million of light pair of heels, and fly over into England.

sp.speaker: Mistress Waf.
sp.p: The time of our meeting? Come?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Seven.

sp.speaker: Mistress Waf.
sp.p: The place.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: In Blackfriars, there take water, keep a loof from the shore, on with your masks, up with your sails, and westward ho

sp.speaker: Mistress Waf.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: O the quick apprehension of women, they'll grope out a man's meaning presently, well, it rests now that I discover myself in my true shape to these gentlewomen's husbands: for though I have played the fool a little to beguile the memory of mine own misfortune, I would not play the knave, though I be taken for a bankrupt, but indeed as in other things, so in that, the world is much deceived in me, for I have yet three thousand pounds in the hands of a sufficient friend, and all my debts discharged. I have received here a letter from my wife ▪ directed to s●ode, wherein she most repentantly intreateth my return, with protestation to give me assured trial of her honesty. I cannot tell what to think of it, but I will put it to the test, there is a great strife between beauty, and chastity, and that which pleaseth many is never free from temptation: as for jealousy, it makes many cuckolds, many fools, and many bankrupts: it may have abused me and not my wife's honesty: I'll try it: but first to my secure and do●ing companion.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.l: I beseech you mistress Tenterhook,
Before God I'll be sick if you will not be merry.

sp.speaker: Mistress Tent.
sp.p: You are a sweet beagle.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Come, because I kept from town a little, let me not live if I did not hear the sickness was in town very hot: in troth thy hair is of an excellent colour since I saw it. O those bright tresses like to threads of gold.

sp.speaker: M●st Tent.
sp.p: Lie, and ashes, suffer much in the city for that comparison.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Here's an honest gentleman will be here by and by, was born at Foolham: his name is Gosling glow-worm.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tent.
sp.p: I know him, what is he?

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: He is a knight: what ailed your husband to be so hasty to arrest me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tent.
sp.p: Shall I speak truly? shall I speak not like a woman.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Why not like a woman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tent.
sp.p: Because women's tongues are like to clocks, if they go too fast they never go true, was I that got my husband to arrest thee, I have.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: I am beholding to you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tent.
sp.p: For sooth I could not come to the speech of you, I think you may be spoken with all now.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: I thank you, I hope you'll bail me cousin?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tent.
sp.p: And yet why should I speak with you, I protest I love my husband

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Tush let not any young woman love a man in years too well.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tent.
sp.p: Why? Mono because he'll die before he can require it.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: I have acquainted wafer and honeysuckle with it, and they allow my wit for't extremely. Enter ambush.o honest sergeant

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Welcome good mistress Tenterhook.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tent.
sp.p: Sergeant I must needs have my cousin go a little way out of town with me and to secure thee, here are two diamonds, they are worth two hundred pound, keep them till I return him.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Well 'tis good security.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tent.
sp.p: Do not come in my husband's sight in the mean time

div.stage: Enter whirl, glow-worm, Gozling, Linstocke, mistress Honeysuckle, and mistress wafer.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Welcome gallants.

sp.speaker: Whirl.
sp.p: How now monopoly arrested?

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: O my little Honysuckle art come to visit a prisoner?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hony.
sp.p: Yes faith as gentlemen visit merchants, to fare well, or as poet's young quaint revellers, to laugh at them. Sirrah if I were some foolish justice, if I would not beg thy wit never trust me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tent.
sp.p: Why I pray you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hony.
sp.p:
Because it hath been concealed all this while, but come shall we to boat, we are furnished for attendants as ladies are,
we have our fools, and our ushers.

sp.speaker: Sir. Goz.
sp.p: I thank you madam, I shall meet your wit in the close one day.

sp.speaker: Mistress Waf.
sp.p: Sirrah, thou knowest my husband keeps a kennel of hounds?

sp.speaker: Mistress Hony.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Whirl.
sp.p: Doth thy husband love venery?

sp.speaker: Mistress Waf.
sp.p: Venery?

sp.speaker: Whirl.
sp.p: Ay, hunting, and venery are words of one signification.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Waf.
sp.p: Your two husband, and he have made a match to go find a hare about Busty Causy.

sp.speaker: Mistress Tent.
sp.p: They'll keep an excellent house till we come home again.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ho.
sp.p: O excellent, a Spanish dinner, a pilchard, and a Dutch supper, butter and onions.

sp.speaker: Lynst.
sp.p: O thou art a mad wench.

sp.speaker: Mistress Tent.
