sp.p: Sergeant carry this ell of cambric to mistress bird. tell her but that it is a rough tide, and that she fears the water, she should have gone with us.

sp.speaker: Sir Goz.
sp.p: O thou hast an excellent wit.

sp.speaker: Whirl.
sp.p: To boat hay?

sp.speaker: Mistress Hony.
sp.p: Sir Gozlin? I do take it your legs are married.

sp.speaker: Sir Goz.
sp.p: Why mistress?

sp.speaker: Mistress Honi.
sp.p: They look so thin upon it.

sp.speaker: Sir Goz.
sp.p: Ever since I measured with your husband, I have shrunk in the cal●e.

sp.speaker: Mistress Hony.
sp.p: And yet you have a sweet tooth in your head.

sp.speaker: Sir Goz.
sp.p: O well dealt for the calf's head, you may talk what you will of legs, and rising in the small, and swelling beneath the garter. But 'tis certain when lank thighs brought long stockings out of fashion, the courtier's leg, and his slender tilting staff grew both of a bigness. Come for Brainford.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Good morrow mistress Luce: how did you take your rest tonight ? how doth your good worship like your lodging? what will you have to breakfast?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: A pox of the knight that was here last night, he promised to have sent me some wild foul; he was drunk I'll bestowed else.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Why do not you think he will send them?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Hang them: ●●s no more in fashion for them to keep their promises, then 'tis for men to pay their debts. He will lie faster than a dog trots: what a filthy knocking was at door last night; some puny inn-a-court-men, I'll hold my contribution.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p:
Yes in troth were they, civil gentlemen without beards,
but to say the truth, I did take exceptions at their knocking: took them aside and said to them: gentlemen this is not well, that you should come in this habit, cloaks and rapiers, boots and spurs, I protest to you, those that be your ancients in the house would have come to my house in their caps and gowns, civilly, and modestly. I promise you they might have been taken for citizens, but that they talk more liker fools. Who knocks there? up into your chamber. Enter master Honisuckle.who are you, some man of credit? that you come in mufled thus.

sp.speaker: Honi.
sp.p: Who's above?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Let me see your face first. O master Honisuckle, why the old party: the old party.

sp.speaker: Honi.
sp.p: Pew I will not go up to her: nobody else?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: As I live will you give me some sack? where's opportunity.

sp.speaker: Honi.
sp.p: What dost call her?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Her name is christian, but mistress Luce cannot abide that name, and so she calls her opportunity.

sp.speaker: Honi.
sp.p: Very good, good.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.l: Is't a shilling, bring the rest in aquavite .
Come shall's go to noddy.

sp.speaker: Honi.
sp.p: I and thou wilt for half an hour.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Here are the cards? deal, God send me deuces and aces with a court card, and I shall get by it.

sp.speaker: Honi.
sp.p: That can make thee nothing.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Yes if I have a coat card turn up.

sp.speaker: Honi.
sp.p: I show four games?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: By my troth I must show all and little enough to, six games: play your single game, I shall double with you anon.
sp.l: Pray you lend me some silver to count my games?
How now is it good sack?

sp.speaker: Chri:
sp.p: There's a gentleman at door would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Ho:
sp.p: God's so, I will not be seen by any means.

sp.speaker: Bird:
sp.p: Into that closet then? What another muffler?

sp.speaker: Ten.
sp.p: How dost thou mistress Birdlime?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Master Tenterhook the party is above in the dining chamber.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Above.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: All alone?

sp.speaker: Honi.
sp.p: Is he gone up? who wast I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: By this sack I will not tell you I say that you were a country gentleman, or a citizen that hath a young wife, or an inn of chancery man, should I tell you? Pardon me; this sack tastes of horse flesh, I warrant you the leg of a dead horse hangs in the but of sack to keep it quick?

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: I beseech thee good mistress Birdlime tell me who it was.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: O God sir we are sworn to secrecy as well as surgeons. Come drink to me, and let's to our game.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Who am I?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: You, pray you unblind me, captain whirlpool, no master Linstock: pray unblind me, you are not sir Gosling glow-worm, for he wears no rings of his fingers! Master freeze-leather, oh you are George the drawer at the mitre, pray you unblind me, captain Puckfoist, master counterpane the lawyer, what the devil mean you, beshrew your heart you have a very dry hand, are you not mine host dogbolt of Brainford, mistress Birdlyme, master Honysuckle, master wafer.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: What the last of all your clients.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O how dost thou good cousin.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: I you have many cousins.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Faith I can name many that I do not know, and suppose I did know them what then? I will suffer one to keep me in diet, another in apparel; another in physic; another to pay my house rent. I am just of the nature of alchemy; I will suffer every plodding fool to spend money upon me, marry none but some worthy friend to enjoy my more retired and useful faithfulness.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Your love, your love.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O ay, 'tis the curse that is laid upon our quality, what we glean from others we lavish upon some trothless well-faced younger brother, that loves us only for maintenance.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Hast a good term Luce?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p:
A pox on the term, and now I think on't, says a gentleman last night let the pox be in the town seven year, Westminster never breeds cobwebs, and yet 'tis as catching as the plague, though not also general, there be a thousand bragging lacks in ▪ London, that will protest they can wrest comfort from me when (I swear) not one of them know whether my palm be moist or
not: in troth I love thee: you promised me seven else of cambric. Wafer knocks and enters, who's that knocks?

sp.speaker: Honi.
sp.p: What, more sacks to the mill, I'll to my old retirement.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: How doth your good worship, passion of my heart, what shift shall I make. How hath your good wor. done, a long time?

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: Very well God godamercy.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Your good worsh. I think be riding out of town.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: Yes believe me, I love to be once a week a horseback, for methinks nothing sets a man out, better than a horse.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: 'Tis certain, nothing sets a woman out better than a man.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: What, is missed. Luce above?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Yes truly.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: Not any company with her.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Company? Shall I say to your good worship and not lie, she hath had no company (Let me see how long it was since your wor. was hear) you w●t to a butcher's feast at cuckolds-haven the next day after saint Luke's day. Not this fortnight, in good truth.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: Alas, good soul.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: And why was it? Go to, go to, I think you know better than I ▪ the wench asketh every day when will m. wafer be here: and if knights ask for her, she cries out at stairhead, as you love my life let 'em not come up, I'll do myself violence if they enter: have not you promised her somewhat?

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: Faith, I think she loves me.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Loues: well, would you knew what I know, than you would say somewhat. In good faith she's very poor, all her gowns are at pawn: she owes me five pound for her diet, besides 40. sh. I lent her to redeem two half silk kirtles from the brokers, and do you think she needed be in debt thus, if she thought not of somebody.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: Good honest wench.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Nay in troth, she's now entering into bond for 5. pounds more, the scrivener is but new gone up to take her bond.

sp.speaker: Wafer
sp.p: Come, let her not enter into bond, I'll lend her 5. pound, I'll pay the rest of her debts, call down the scrivener?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: I pray you when he comes down, stand muffled, and I'll tell him you are her brother.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: If a man have a good honest wench, that lives wholly to his use, let him not see her want.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p:
O, mist. Luce, mist. Luce, you are the most unfortunate
gentlewoman that ever breathed: your young wild brother came newly out of the country, he calls me bawd, swears I keep a bawdy house, says his sister is turned whore, and that he will kill, and slay any man that he finds in her company.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: What conveyance will you make with mistress Birdlime.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O God let him not come up, 'tis the swaggringst wild-oats.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: I have pacified him somewhat, for I told him, that you were a scrivener come to take a band of her, now as you go forth say she might have had so much money if she had pleased, and say, she is an honest gentlewoman and all will be well.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Enough, farewell good luce.

sp.speaker: Btrd.
sp.p: Come change your voice, and muffle you.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: What trick should this be, I have never a brother, I'll hold my life some franker customer is come, that she slides him off so smoothly.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: The gentlewoman is an honest gentlewoman as any is in London, and should have had thrice as much money upon her single bond for the good report I hear of her.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: No sir her friends can furnish her with money.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: By this light I should know that voice, wafer, od'sfoot are you the gentlewoman's brother?

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: Are your turned a scrivener Tenterhook?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: I am spoilt.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: Tricks of mistress Birdlyme by this light.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: Hoick covert, hoick covert, why gentlemen is this your hunting?

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: A consort, what make you here honeysuckle?

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: Nay what make you two hear, oh excellent mistress bird. thou hast more tricks in thee then a punk hath uncles, cousins, brothers. Sons or fathers: an infinite company.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: If I did it not to make your good worships merry, never believe me, I will drink to your worship a glass of sack.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: God save you.

sp.speaker: Hony and Waf.
sp.p: Master Justiniano's welcome from Stoad.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Why gentlemen I never came there.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Never there ● where have you been then?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Marry your daily guest I thank you.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Ours.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: I yours.

I was the pedant that learned your wives to write, I was the collier that brought you news your child was sick, but the truth is, for ought I know, the child is in health, and your wives are gone to make merry at Brainford.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: By my troth good wenches, they little dream where we are now ▪

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: You little dream what gallants are with them.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Gallants with them! I de laugh at that.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Four gallants by this light, mai ▪ monopoly is one of them.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Monopoly? I'd laugh at that in faith.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Would you laugh at that! why do ye laugh at it then, they are there by this time, I cannot stay to give you more particular intelligence: I have received a letter from my wife hear, if you will call me at Putney, I'll bear you company.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Uds'foot what a rogue is sergeant ambush, I'll undo him by this light.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: I met sergeant ambush, and willed him come to this house to you presently, so gentlemen I leave you ● bawd I have nothing to say to you now; do not think to much in so dangerous a matter for in women's matters 'tis more dangerous to stand long deliberating ▪ than before a battle.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: This fellow's poverty hath made him an arrant knave.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Will your worship drink any aquavitae?

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Apox on your aquavitae. Monopoly, that my wife urged me to arrest gone to Brainford. Enter ambush.here's comes the varlet.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: I am come sir to know your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: What hath monopoly paid the money yet?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: No sir, but he sent for money.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: You have not carried him to the counter, he is at your house still.

sp.speaker: Amb:
sp.p: O lord I sir as melancholic etc.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: You lie like an arrant varlet, by this candle I laugh at the jest

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: And yet he's ready to cry.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: He's gone with my wife to Brainford, and there be any law in England I'll tickle ye for this.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Do your worst, for I have good security and I care not, besides it was his cousin your wine's pleasure that he should go along with her.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Hoy day, her cousin, ●el sir, your security.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Why sir two diamonds here.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.l: O my heart: my wife's two diamonds,
Well, you'll go along and justify this.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: That I will sir.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Who am I?

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: What the murrain care I who you are, hold off your fingers, or I'll cut them with this diamond.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I'll see 'em i'faith,
So, I'll keep these diamonds tell I have my silk gown, and six else of cambric.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: By this light you shall not.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: No, what do you think you have fops in hand, sue me for them.

sp.speaker: Waf. and Hony.
sp.p: As you respect your credit let's go.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Good luce as you love me let me have them, it stands upon my credit, thou shalt have any thing, take my purse.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I will not be crossed in my humour sir.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: You are a damned filthy punk, what an unfortunate rogue was I, that ever I came into this house.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Do not spurn anybody in my house you were best.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Well, well.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Excellent luce, the getting of these two diamonds mai● chance to save the gentlewomen's credit; thou heardst all.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O ay, and by my troth pity them, what a filthy knave was that betrayed them.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: One that put me into pitiful fear, master Justiniano here hath laid lurking like a sheep-biter, and in my knowledge hath drawn these gentlewomen to this misfortune: but I'll down to queen-hive, and the watermen which were wont to carry you to Lambeth marsh, shall carry me thither: it may be I may come before them; I think I shall pray more, what for sear of the water, and for my good success than I did this twelvemonth.

div.head: Scaena 2
div.stage: Enter the Earl and three serving-men.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Have you perfumed this chamber?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Yes my lord.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.p: The banquet?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: It stands ready.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: Go, let music
Charm with her excellent voice an awful silence
through all this building, that her sphery soul
May (On the wings of air) in thousand forms
Invisibly fly, yet be enjoyed. Away.

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.p: Does my lord mean to conjure that he draws this strange characters.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.p: He does: but we shall see neither the spirit that rises, nor the circle it rises in.

sp.speaker: 3 servant
sp.p: 'Twould make our hair stand up an end if we should, come fools come, meddle not with his matters, lords may do any thing.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: This night shall my desires be amply crowned,
And all those powers, that taste of man in us,
Shall now aspire that point of happiness,
Beyond which, sensual eyes never look, (Sweet pleasure!)
Delicious pleasure? Earth's supremest good,
The spring of blood, though it dry up our blood.
Rob me of that, (Though to be drunk with pleasure,
As rank excess even in best things is bad;
Turns man into a beast) yet that being gone,
A horse and this (The goodliest shape) all one.
We feed: wear rich attires: and strive to cleave
The stars with marble towers, fight battles: spend
Our blood to buy us names: and in iron hold
Will we eat roots, to imprison fugitive gold:
But to do thus, what spell can us excite,
This the strong magic of our appetite:
To feast which richly, life itself undoes,
Who'd not die thus? to see, and then to choose
Why even those that starve in voluntary wants,
And to advance the mind, keep the flesh poor,
The world enjoying them, they not the world,
Would they do this, but that they are proud to suck
A sweetness from such sourness; let 'em so,
The torrent of my appetite shall flow
With happier stream. A woman! O, the spirit
And extract of creation! This, this night,
The sun shall envy. What cold checks our blood?
Her body is the chariot of my soul,
her eyes my body's light, which if I want,
Life wants, or if possess, I undo her;
Turn her into a devil, whom I adore,
By scorching her with the hot steam of lust,
'Tis but a minute's pleasure: and the sin
Scarce acted is repented. Shun it then:
Oh he that can abstain, is more than man!
Tush. Resolvest thou to do ill: be not precise
Who writes of virtue best, are slaves to vice,
The music sounds all arum to my blood,
What's bad I follow, yet I see what's good.

div.stage: While the song is heard. The Earl draws a curtain and sets forth a banquet: he then exit, and enters presently with parenthesis attired like his wife masked: leads him to the table, places him in a chair, and in dumb signs, courts him, till the song be done.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: Fair! be not doubly masked: with that and night,
Beauty (Like gold) being used becomes more bright.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Will it please your lordship to sit, I shall receive small pleasure if I see your lordship stand.

sp.speaker: Ear:
sp.p: Witch, hag, what art thou proud damnation?

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: A merchant's wife.

sp.speaker: Ear:
sp.p: Fury who raised thee up, what comest thou for!

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: For a banquet.

sp.speaker: Ear:
sp.l: I am abused, deluded: speak what art thou?
Uds death speak, or I'll kill thee: in that habit
I looked to find an angel, but thy face,
Shows thou'rt a devil.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: My face is as God made it my lord: I am no devil unless women be devils, but men find 'em not so, for they daily hunt for them.

sp.speaker: Ear:
sp.p: What art thou that dost cozen me thus?

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: A merchant's wife I say: Justiniano's wife. She, whom that long birding piece of yours, I mean that wicked mother Birdlyme caught for your honour. Why my lord, has your lordship forgotten how ye courted me last morning.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.p: The devil I did.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Kissed me last morning.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.p: Succubus ▪ not thee.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Gave me this jewel last morning.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.p: Not to thee harpy.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: To me upon mine honesty, swore you would build me a lodging by the Thames side with a watergate to it: or else take me a lodging in Coleharbour.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.p: I swore so.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Or keep me in a labyrinth as Harry kept Rosamond where the minotaur my husband should not enter.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.p: I sware so, but Gipsy not to thee?

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: To me upon my honour, hard was the siege, which you laid to the crystal walls of my chastity, but I held out you know: but because I cannot be too stony hearted, I yielded my lord, by this token my lord (Which token lies at my heart like lead) but by this token my lord, that this night you should commit that sin which we all know with me.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.p: The●?

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Do I look ugly, that you put thee upon me: did I give you my hand to horn my head, that's to say my husband, and is it come to thee: is my face a filthier face, now it is yours, then when it was his: or have I two faces under one hood. I confess I have laid mine eyes in brine, and that may change the copy. But my lord I know what I am.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: A sorceress, thou shalt witch mine ears no more,
If thou canst pray, do't quickly for thou diest.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.l: I can pray but I will not die, thou liest:
My lord there drops your lady; and now know,
Thou unseasonable lecher, I am her husband
Whom thou wouldst make whore, read: she speaks there thus,
Unless I came to her, her hand should free
Her chastity from blemish, proud I was
Of her brave mind, I came, and seeing what slavery
Poverty, and the frailty of her sex
H●d, and was like to make her subject to,
I begged that she would die, my suit was granted,
I poisoned her, thy lust there strikes her dead,
Horns feared, plague worse, than sticking on the head.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: O God thou hast undone thyself and me,
None live to match this piece, thou art too bloody,
Yet for her sake, whom I'll embalm with tears,
this act with her I bury, and to quit
Thy loss of such a jewel, thou shalt share
My living with me, come embrace.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: Villain, damned merciless slave, I'll torture thee
To every inch of flesh: what ho: help, who's there?
Come hither: here's a murderer, bind him. How now,
What noise is this.

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.p: My lord there are three citizens face me down, that here's one master parenthesis a schoolmaster with your lordship and desire he may be forthcoming to 'em.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.l: That borrowed name is mine. Shift for yourselves:
Away, shift for yourselves; fly, I am taken.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: Why should they fly thou screech-owl.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.l: I will tell thee,
Those three are partners with me in the murder,
We four commixed the poison, shift for yourselves.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: Stops mouth, and drag him back: entreat 'em enter.
O what a conflict feel I in my blood,
I would I were less great to be more good:
You're welcome, wherefore came you! guard the doors;
When I behold that object, all my senses
Revolt from reason, he that offers flight,
Drops down a corse.

sp.speaker: Al. 3.
sp.l: A corse?

sp.speaker: 1. Servant
sp.l: I a corse, do you scorn to be worms meat more than she?

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.l: See gentlemen, the Italian that does scorn,
Beneath the moon, no baseness like the horn,
Has poured through all the veins of yond chaste bosom,
Strong poison to preserve it from that plague,
This fleshy lord: he doted on my wife,
He would have wrought on her and played on me.
But to pare off these brims, I cut off her,
And gulled him with this lie, that you had hands
Dipped in her blood with mine, but this I did,
That his staind age and name might not be hid.
My act (Though vild) the world shall crown as just,
I shall die eleere, when he lives soiled with lust:
But come: rise Moll. Awake sweet Moll, thou'st played
The woman rarely, counterfeited well.

sp.speaker: 1. Servant
sp.l: Sure sh'as nine lives.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.l: See, Lucrece is not slain,
Her eyes which lust called suns, have their first beams,
And all these frightments are but idle dreams:
Yet (Afore Jove) she had her knife prepared
To let his blood forth ere it should run black?
Do not these open cuts now, cool your back?
Methinks they should: when vice sees with broad eyes
Her ugly form, she does herself despise.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: Mirror of dames, I look upon thee now,
As men long blind, (Having recovered sight)
Amazed: scarce able are to endure the light:
Mine own shame strikes me dumb: hence forth the book
I'll read shall be thy mind, and not thy look.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: I would either we were at Brainford to see our wives, or our wives here to see this pageant.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: So would I, I stand upon thorns.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: The jewels which I gave you: wear: your fortunes,
I'll raise on golden pillars: fare you well,
Lust in old age like burned straw, does even choke
The kindlers, and consumes, in stinking smoke.

sp.speaker: P●r.
sp.p: You may follow your lord by the smoke, airs.

sp.speaker: 1. Servant
sp.p: If fortune had favoured him, we might have followed you by the horns.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Fortune favours fools, your lords a wise lord: so: how now? ha? This is that makes me fat now, is't not ratsbane to you gentlemen, as pap was to Nestor, but I know the invisible sins of your wives hang at your eyelids, and that makes you so heavy headed.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: If I do take 'em napping I know what I'll do.

sp.speaker: Honi.
sp.p: I'll nap some of them.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: That villain Monopoly, and that sir Gozlin treads 'em all.

sp.speaker: Wafer.
sp.p: Would I might come to that treading.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p:
Ha ha, sound I: come Moll: the book of the siege of Ostend, writ by one that dropped in the action, will never sell so well, as a report of the siege between this gr●●e, this wicked elder and
thy self, an impression of you two, would away in a may-morning: was it ever heard that such tyrings, were brought away from a lord by any wench but thee Moll, without paying, unless the wench coney-catched him? go thy thy ways: if all the great Turks concubines were but like thee, the ten-penny-infidel should never need keep so many geldings to neigh over 'em: come shall this western voyage hold my hearts?

sp.speaker: All 3
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Yes, yes: 'sfoot you speak as if you had no hearts, and look as if you were going westward indeed: to see how plain dealing women can pull down men: Moll you'll help us to catch smelts too?

sp.speaker: Mistress Iust.
sp.p: If you be pleased.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Never better since I wore a smock.

sp.speaker: Honi.
sp.p: I fear our oars have given us the bag.

sp.speaker: Wafer.
sp.p: Good, I'd laughed at that.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: If they have, would where's might give them the bottle: come march whilst the women double their files: married men fee, there's comfort: the moons up: fore don Phoebus, I doubt we shall have a frost this night, her horns are so sharp: do you not feel it bite.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: I do, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: But we'll sit upon one another's skirts boat, and lie close in straw, like the hoary courtier. Set on to Brainford now: where if you meet frail wives, ne'er swear 'gainst horns, in vain dame nature strives.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter monopoly, whirlpool, Lynstock, and their 〈◊〉, Judith, Mabell, and Clare, their hats off.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Why chamberlain? will not these fiddlers be drawn forth? are they not in tune yet? Or are the rogues afraid ath' statute, and dare not travel so far without a passport?

sp.speaker: Whir.
sp.p: What chamberlain?

sp.speaker: Lynst.
sp.p: Where's mine host? what chamberlain.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Anon sir, here sir, at hand sir.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Where's this noise? what a lousy towns this? Has Brainford no music in't.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p:
They are but rozining sir, and they'll scrape themselves
into your company presently.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Plague a their cat's guts, and their scraping: dost not see women here, and can wethinkst thou be without a noise then?

sp.speaker: Chamberlain
sp.p: The troth is sir, one of the poor instruments caught a sore mischance last night: his most base bridge fell down, and belike they are making a gathering for the reparations of that.

sp.speaker: Whir.
sp.p: When they come, let's have 'em with apox.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Well sir, you shall sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Stay Chamberlin: where's our knight sir Gozlin? where's sir Gozlin.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Troth sir, my master, and sir Gozlin are guzzling: they are dabbling together fathom deep: the knight hath drunk so much health to the gentleman yonder, on his knees, that he has almost lost the use of his legs.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: O for love, let none of 'em enter our room, fie.

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: I would not have 'em cast up their accounts here, for more than they mean to be drunk this twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Good chamberlain keep them and their healths out of our company. I warrant you, their healths shall not hurt you.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Ay, well said: they're none of our giving: let 'em keep their own quarter: nay I told you the man would soak him if he were ten knights: if he were a knight of gold they'd fetch him over.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Out upon him?

sp.speaker: Whirl.
sp.p: There's a lieutenant and a captain amongst 'em too.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: Nay, then look to have somebody lie on the earth fort: it's ordinary for your lief tenant to be drunk with your captain, and your captain to cast with your knight.

sp.speaker: Cla:
sp.p: Did you never hear how sir Fabian Scarerow (Even such another) took me up one night before my husband being in wine.

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: No indeed, how was it?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: But I think I took him down with a witness,

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.p: How? Good Tenterhooke.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Nay I'll have all your ears take part of it.

sp.speaker: Omni.
sp.p: Come, on then.

sp.speaker: Cla:
sp.p: Hevsd to frequent me and my husband divers times ▪ and at last comes he out one morning to my husband, and says, master Tenterhook says he, I must trouble you to lend me 200. pound about a commodity which I am to deal in, and what was that commodity but his knighthood.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Why you shall master scarecrow says my good man: so within a little while after, master Fabian was created knight.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Created a knight! that's no good heraldry: you must say dubbed.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And why not created prey.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: I well done, put him down at's own weapon.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Not created, why all things have their being by creation.

sp.speaker: Lynst.
sp.p: Yes by my faith is't.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: But to return to my tale.

sp.speaker: Whirl.
sp.p: I marry: mark now.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: When he had climbed up this costly ladder of preferment, he disburses the money back again very honourably: comes home, and was by my husband invited to supper: there supped with us besides, another gentleman incident to the court, one that had bespoke me of my husband to help me into the banqueting house and see the revelling: a young gentleman, and that wag (Our schoolmaster) master parenthesis, for I remember he said grace, methinks I see him yet, how he turned up the white a'th eye, when he came to the last gasp, and that he was almost past grace.

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: Nay he can do't.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: All supper time, my new-minted knight, made wine the waggon to his meat, for it ran down his throat so fast, that before my chambermaid had taken half up, he was not scarce able to stand.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: A general fault at citizens' tables.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And I thinking to play upon him, asked him, sir Fabian scarecrow quoth I, what pretty gentlewoman will you raise up now to stal her your lady? but he like a foul-mouthed man, swore zounds I'll stal never a punk in England. A lady, there's two many already: oh fie sir Fabian (Quoth I) will you call her that shall be your wife such an odious name! and then he sets out a throat and swore again (Like a stinking breathed knight as he was) that women were like horse.

sp.speaker: Jud. and mub.
sp.p: O filthy knave.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: They'd break over any hedge to change their pasture, th● it were worse: fie man fie, (Says the gentlewoman.)

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
And he bristling up his beard to rail at her too, I cut him
over the thumbs thus: why sir Fabian Searcrow did I incense my husband to lend you so much money upon your bare word, and do you backbite my friends, and me so our faces! I thought you had had more perseverance; if you bore a knightly and a degenerous mind you would scorn it: you had wont to be more deformable amongst women: fie, that you'll be so humoursome: here was nobody so egregious towards you sir Fabian! and thus in good sadness, I gave him the best words I could pick out to make him ashamed of his doings.

sp.speaker: Whrl.
sp.p: And how took he this correction.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Very heavily: for he slept presently upon't: and in the morning was the sorriest knight, and I warrant is so to this day, that lives by bread in England.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: To fee what wine and women can do, the one makes a man not to have a word to throw at a dog, the other makes a man to eat his own words though they were never so filthy.

sp.speaker: Whirl.
sp.p: I see these fiddlers cannot build up their bridge, that some music may come over us.

sp.speaker: Lynst.
sp.p: No faith they are drunk too, what shall's do therefore.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Sit up at cards all night?

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: That's serning man's fashion.

sp.speaker: Whirl.
sp.p: Drink burned wine and eggs then?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: That's an exercise for your suburb wenches.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: No no, let's set upon our posset and so march to bed, for I begin to wax light with having my natural sleep puld-out a mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Agreed: beet so, the sack posset and to bed.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: What chamberlain? I must take a pipe of tobacco.

sp.speaker: 3. Woman.
sp.p: Not here, not here, not here.

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: I'll rather love a man that takes a purse, then him that takes tobacco.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: By my little finger I'll break all your pipes, and burn the case, and the box too, and you draw out your stinking smoke afore me.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Prithee good mistress 〈◊〉, I'll ha' done in a trice.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Do you long to have me swoon?

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: I'll use but half a pipe introth.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Do you long to see me lie at your feet!

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Smell to't: ●i● perfumed.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: O God? O God? you anger me: you stir my blood: you move me: you make me spoil a good face with frowning at you: this was ever your fashion, so to smoke my husband when you come home, that I could not abide him in mine eye: he was a moat in it methought a month after: pray spawle in another room: fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Well, well, come, we'll for once feed her humour.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Get two rooms off at least if you love us.

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: Three, three, master Linstock three.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Sfoot we'll dance to Norwich, and take it there, if you'll stay till we return again? Here's a stir, you'll ill abide a fiery face, that cannot endure a smoky nose.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Come let's satisfy our appetite.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: And that will be hard for us, but we'll do our best.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: So: are they departed? What string may we three think that these three gallants harp upon, by bringing us to this sinful town of Brainford? ha?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: I know what string they would harp upon, if they could put us into the right tune.

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: I know what one of 'em buzzed in mine ear, till like a these in a candle, he made mine ears burn, but I swore to say nothing.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I know as verily they hope, and brag one to another, that this night they'll row westward in our husband's whirries, as we hope to be rowed to London to morrow morning in a pair of oars. But wenches let's be wise, and make rooks of them that I warrant are now setting pursenets to coney-catch us.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Content.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: They shall know that citizens wives have wit enough to out strip twenty such gulls; though we are merry, let's not be mad: be as wanton as new married wives, as fantastic and light headed to the eye, as feather-makers, but as pure about the heart, as if we dwelled amongst 'em in black friars.

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: We'll eat and drink with 'em.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
O yes: eat with 'em as hungerly as soldiers: drink ▪ as if we were froes: talk as freely as jesters, but do as little as misers. Who (Like dry nurses) have great breasts but give no milk. It were better we should laugh at their popinjays, then
live in fear of their prating tongues: though we lie all night out of the city, they shall not find country wenches of us: but since we ha' brought 'em thus far into a fool's paradise, leave 'em in't: the jest shall be a stock to maintain us and our pewfellows in laughing at christenings, cryings out, and upsittings this 12. month: how say you wenches, have I set the saddle on the right horse.

sp.speaker: Boath.
sp.p: O 'twill be excellent.

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: But how shall we shift 'em off?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Not as ill debtors do their creditors (With good words) but as lawyers do their clients when their overthrown, by some new knavish trick: and thus it shall be: one of us must dissemble to be suddenly very sick.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: I'll be she.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Nay, though we can all dissemble well, yet I'll be she: for men are so jealous, or rather envious of one another's happiness (Especially in this out of town gossipings) that he who shall miss his hen, if he be a right cock indeed, will watch the other from treading.

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: That's certain, I know that by myself.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And like Esop's dog, unless himself might eat hay, will lie in the manger and starve: but he'll hinder the horse from eating any: besides it will be as good as a Welsh hook for you to keep out the other at the staff's end: for you may boldly stand upon this point, that unless every man's heels may be tripped up, you scorn to play at football.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: That's certaine● peace I hear them spitting after their tobacco.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: A chair, a chair, one of you keep as great a coil and calling, and as if you ran for a midwife: th'other hold my head: whilst I cut my lace.

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: Passion of me? master Monopoly, master linstock and you be men, help to daw mistress Tenterhook: oh quickly, quickly, she's sick and taken with an agony.

div.stage: Enter as she cries Monopohe, whirlpool, and Lynstocke,

sp.speaker: Omni.
sp.p: Sick? How? how now? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Monop.
sp.p: Sweet Clare call up thy spirits.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: O master Monopoly, my spirits will not comet a my calling, I am terrible and ill: sure, sure, I'm struck with some wicked planet, for it 〈◊〉 my very heart: o I feel myself worse and worse.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Some burned sack for her good wenche●: or possit drink, pox a this rogue chamberlain, one of you call him: how her pulses beat: a draught of cinnamon water now for her, were better than two tankards out of the Thames: how now? Ha.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ill, ill, ill, ill, ill.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: I'm accursed to spend money in this town of iniquity: there's no good thing ever comes out of it: and it stands upon such musty ground, by reason of the river, that I cannot see how a tender woman can do well in't, 'sfoot? Sick now? cast down now 'tis come to the push.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: My mind misgives me that all's not sound at London.

sp.speaker: Whirle.
sp.p: Pox on 'em that be not sound, what need that touch you?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I fear you'll never carry me thither.

sp.speaker: Omni.
sp.p: Puh, puh, say not so.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Pray let my clothes be utterly undone, and then lay me in my bed.

sp.speaker: Lynst.
sp.p: Walk up and down a little.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: O master Linstock, 'tis no walking will serve my turn: have me to bed good sweet mistress Honisuckle, I doubt that old hag Gillian of Brainford has bewitched me.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Look to her good wenches.

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: I so we will, and to you too: this was excellent.

sp.speaker: Whirle.
sp.p: This is strange.

sp.speaker: Lynst.
sp.p: Villainous spiteful luck: no matter, th', other two hold ●yas.

sp.speaker: Whirle.
sp.p: Peace, mark how he's nipped: nothing grieves me so much as that poor Pyramus here must have a wall this night between him and his Thisbe.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: No remedy trusty Troilus: and it grieves me as much, that you'll want your false Cressida tonight , for here's no sir Pandarus to usher you into your chamber.

sp.speaker: Lynst.
sp.p: I'll summon a parley to one of the wenches, and see how all goes.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: No whispering with the common enemy by this iron: he sees the devil that sees how all goes amongst the women tonight : nay 'sfoot? If I stand piping till you dance, damn me.

sp.speaker: Lyn.
sp.p: Why you'll let me call to 'em but at the keyhole.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p:
Puh, good master Linstock, I'll not stand by whilst you give fire at your keyholes? I'll hold no trencher till another ●eedes: no stirrup till another gets up: be no doorkeeper. I
ha' not been so often at court, but I know what the backside of the hangings are made of I'll trust none under a piece of tapestry, viz. a coverlet.

sp.speaker: Whirl.
sp.p: What will you say if the wenches do this to gull us?

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: No matter, I'll not be doubly gulled, by them and by you: go, will you take the lease of the next chamber and do as I do.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: And what's that?

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Any villainy in your company, but nothing out on't will you sit up, or lie by't.

sp.speaker: Whirl.
sp.p: Nay lie sure, for lying is most in fashion.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Troth then; I'll have you before me.

sp.speaker: Booth.
sp.p: It shall be yours.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Yours i'faith: I'll play Janus with two faces and look asquint both ways for one night.

sp.speaker: Lyn.
sp.p: Well sir, you shall be our doorkeeper.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.l: Since we must swim, let's leap into one flood,
We'll either be all naught, or else all good.

div.stage: Enter a noise of fiddlers, following the Chamberlyn.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Come, come, come, follow me, follow me. I warrant you ha' lost more by not falling into a sound last night, than ever you got at one Job since it pleased to make you a noise: I can tell you, gold is no money with them: follow me and fum, as you go; you shall put something into their ears, whilst I provide to put something into their bellies. Follow close and sum —

div.stage: Enter sir Gozlin and Birdlime pulled along by him.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: What kin art thou to Long-meg of Westminster? thou'rt like her.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Somewhat a like sir at a blush, nothing a kin sir, saving in height of mind, and that she was a goodly woman.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p:
Mary Ambree, do not you know me? had not I a sight of this sweet phisnomy at rhenish-wine house! ha last day ith' stillyard ha! whither art bound galley-foist? whether art
bound? whence comest thou female yeoman — a the guard?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: From London sir.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: Dost come to keep the door Ascapart.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: My reparations hither is to speak with the gentlewoman here that drunk with your worship at the Dutchhouse of meeting.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: Drunk with me, you lie, not drunk with me: but i'faith what wouldst with the women? they are a-bed : art not a midwife? one of hem told me thou wert a night woman.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: I ha' brought some women a-bed , in my time sir.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: I and some young men too, hast not Pandora? how now! where's this noise.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: I'll commit your worship.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: To the stocks? art a justice? shalt not commit me: dance first i'faith, why scrapers, appear under the wenches comical window, byth' lord! Uds daggers? cannot sin be set ashore once in a reign upon your country quarters, but it must have fiddling? what set of villains are you, you perpetual ragamuffins?

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: The town consort sir.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Consort with a pox? cannot the shaking of the sheets be danced without your town piping? nay then let all hell roar

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: I beseech you sir, put up yours, and we'll put up ours:

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: Play you lousy Hungarians: see, look the maypole is set up, we'll dance about it: keep this circle Maquerelle.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: I am no mackerel, and I'll keep no circles.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: Play, life of Pharaoh play, the bawd shall teach me a Scotch jig.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Bawd! I defy thee and thy jigs whatsoever thou art: were I in place where, I'd make thee prove thy words.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: I would prove 'em mother best be trussed: why do not I know you Granam? and that sugar-loaf? ha! do I not Magara.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: I am none of your Megges, do not nickname me so: I will not be nicked.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p:
You will not: you will not: how many of my name (Of the glowworms) have paid for your furred gowns, thou
woman's broker.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: No sir, I scorn to be beholding to any glow-worm that lives upon earth for my fur: I can keep myself warm without glowworms.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: Canst sing wood-pecker? come sing and wake 'em.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Would you should well know it, I am no singing woman.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: Howle then! sfoot sing, or howl, or I'll break your ostrich eggshell there.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: My egg hurts not you, what do you mean to fl●rish so.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: Sing Madge, Madge, sing owlet.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: How can I sing with such a sour face — I am haunted with a cough and cannot sing.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: One of your instruments mountebanks, come, here clutch: clutch.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Alas sir, I'm an old woman, and know not how to clutch an instrument.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: Look mark to and fro as I 〈◊〉 it: make a noise: it's no matter: any hunts up, to waken vice.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: I shall never rub it in tune.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: Will you scrape?

sp.speaker: Biod.
sp.p: So you will let me go into the parties, I will saw, and make a noise.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: Do then: shatt into the parties, and part 'em: shalt my lean Lana.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: If I must needs play the fool in my old days, let me have the biggest instrument, because I can hold that best: I shall cough like a broken winded horse, if I gape once to sing once.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: No matter cough out thy lungs.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: No sir, though I'm old, and worm-eaten I'm not so rotten —
Will your worship be rid of me now.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: Fain, as rich-men's heirs would be of their gouty dads: that's the hothouse, where your parties are sweating: amble: go, tell the he parties I have sent 'em a mast 〈◊〉 their ship.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Yes forsooth I'll do your errand.

sp.speaker: Goz.
sp.p: Half musty still by thundering Jove: with what wedge of villainy might I cleave out an hour or two? Fiddlers, come: strike up. march before me, the chamberlain shall put a crown for you into his bill of items: you shall sing bawdy songs under every window ith' town: up will the clowns start, down come the wenches, we'll set the men a fighting the women a scolding, the dogs a barking, you shall go on fiddling, and I follow dancing lantara: curry your instruments: play and away.

div.stage: Enter tenterhook, honeysuckle, wafer, parenthesis, and his wife with ambush and chamberlain.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: Sergeant ambush, as thou'rt an honest fellow, scout in some back room, till the watchword be given for sallying forth.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Duns the mouse.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: — A little low-woman sayest thou, — in a veluet-cappe-and one of 'Him in a beaver? brother Honeysuckle, and brother wafer, hark — they are they.

sp.speaker: Waf,
sp.p: But art sure their husbands are a-bed with 'em?

sp.speaker: Chamberlain
sp.p: I think so sir, I know not, I left 'em together in one room: and what division fell amongst 'em, the fates can discover not I.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Leave us good chamberlain, we are some of their friends: leave us good chamberlain: be merry a little: leave us honest chamberlain —Exit.we are abused, we are bought and sold in Brainford market; never did the sickness of one belied nurse-child, stick so cold to the hearts of three fathers: never were three innocent citizens so horribly, so abominably wrung under the withers.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: What shall we do? how shall we help ourselves?

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: How shall we pull this thorn out off our foot before it rankle?

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p:
Yes, yes, yes, well enough; one of us stay here to watch do you see: to watch: have an eye, have an ear. I and my brother wafer, and mayst Justiniano's, will set the town in an insurrection, bring hither the constable, and his Bill●●●, break open upon hem, take 'em in their wickedness,
and put 'em to their 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Ha, ha, purgation.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: We'll have 'em before some country justice of coram (For we scorn to be bound to the peace) and this justice shall draw his sword in our defence, if we find 'em to be malefactors we'll tickle 'em.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: Agreed: do not say, but 〈◊〉 come.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Are you mad? do you know what you do? whether will you run?

sp.speaker: All 3,
sp.p: To set the town an an uproar.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: An uproar ● will you make the townsmen think, that Londoners never come hither but upon saint 〈◊〉 night? Say you should rattle up the constable: thrash all the country together, hedge in the house with flails, pike-staffs, and pitchforks, take your wife's napping, these western smelts nibbling, and that like so many 〈◊〉; every smith should discover his Venus dancing with Mars, 〈…〉 this plaster cure the headache.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Ay, it wood.

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.p: Nay it should.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Nego, nego, no no, it shall be proved unto you, your heads would ache worse: when women are proclaimed to be light, they strive to be more ●ight, for who dare disprove a proclamation.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: I but when light wives make heavy husbands, let these husbands play mad hamlet; and cry revenge, come, and 〈◊〉 do so.

sp.speaker: Mistress Iust.
sp.p: Pray stay, be not so heady at my entreaty.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: My wife 〈◊〉 you, and I entreat you to have mercy on your 〈◊〉, though you have none over the women. I'll tell you a tale: this last Christmas a citizen and his wife (As it might be one of you) were invited to the revels one night at one of the 〈◊〉 a court: the husband (Having business) trusts his wife thither to take up a room for him before: she did so: but before she went; doubts a rising, what blocks her husband would stumble at, to hinder his entrance, it was consulted upon, by what token, by what trick,, by what banner, or brooch he should be known to be he when he wrapped at the gate:

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: The crowd he was told would be greater, their clamours greater, and able to drown the throats of a shoal of fish wives: he himself therefore 〈◊〉 an excellent watchword, and the sign at which he would hang out himself, should be a horn: he would wind his horn, and that should give 'em warning that he was come.

sp.speaker: All. 3.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: The torchmen and 〈◊〉 had an item to receive him: he comes, rings out his horn with an alarum, enters with a shout, all the house rises (Thinking some sowgelder pressed in) his wife blushed, the company jested, the simple man like a beggar going to the stocks laughed, as not being sensible of his own disgrace, and hereupon the punies set down this decree that no man shall hereafter come to laugh at their revels (If his wife be entered before him) unless he carry his horn about him

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: I'll not trouble them.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: So if you trumpet a broad and preach at the market cross, you wife's shame, 'tis your own shame.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What shall we do then!

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Take my council, I'll ask no fee sort: bar our host: banish mine hosts, beat a way the chamberlain, let the ostlers walk, enter you the chambers peaceably, lock the doors gingerly, look upon your wives woefully, but upon the evildoers, most wickedly.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: What shall we reap by this.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: An excellent harvest, this, you shall hear the poor mouse-trapt-guilty-gentlemen call for mercy; your wiues you shall see kneeling at your feet, and weeping, and wringing, and blushing, and cursing Brainford and crying pardona may pardona may, pardona may, whilst you have the choice to stand either as judges to condemn 'em, beadles to torment 'em, or confessors to absolved 'em: and what a glory will it be for you 3. to kiss your wives like forgetful husbands, to exhort and forgive the young men like pitiful fathers; then to call for oars, than to cry hay for London, than to make a supper, than to drown all in sack and sugar, than to go to bed, and then to rise and open shop, where you may ask any man what he lacks with your cap off, and none shall perceive whether the brims wring you.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: We'll raise no towns.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: No, no, let's knock first.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.p: I that's best I'll summon a parley. —

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Who's there? have you stockfish in hand that you beat so hard: who are you?

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: That's my wife; let Justiniano speak for all they know our tongues.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What a murrain ail these colts, to keep such a kicking? Monopoly.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Is m. Linstock up too, and the captain.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Both are in the field: will you open your door?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: O you are proper gamesters to bring false dice with you from London to cheat yourselves. Is't possible that 3 shallow women should gull. 3. such gallants.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: What means this.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Have we defied you upon the walls all night to open our gates to you ith' morning. Our honest husbands they (Silly men) lie praying in their beds now, that the water under us may not be rough, the tilt that covers us may not be rent, and the straw about our feet may keep our pretty legs warm. I warrant they walk upon queen-hive (As Leander did for hero) to watch for our landing, and should we wrong such kind hearts? would we might ever be troubled with the toothache thee.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: This thing that makes fools of us thus, is my wife.

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: Ay, I knock your bellies full, we hug one another a-bed and lie laughing till we tickle again to remember how we sent you a batfowling.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: An almond parrot: that's my Mab's voice, I know by the sound.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Sfoot you ha' spoilt half already, and you'll spoil all, if you dam not up your 〈◊〉 villainy! nothing but villainy, I'm afraid they have smelled your breathes at the key hole, and now they set you to catch Floūders, whilst in the mean time, the concupiscentious malefactors make 'em ready and take London napping.

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.p: I'll not be gulled so

sp.speaker: Ten.
sp.p: Show yourselves to be men, and break open doors.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Break open doors, and show yourselves to be beasts: if you break open doors, your wives may lay flat burglary to your charge.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: Lay a pudding; burglary.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Will you then turn Coridon's because you are among clowns? shall it be said you have no brains being in Brainford.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Parenthesis we will enter and set upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Well do so: but enter not so that all the country may cry shame of your doings: knock 'em down, burst open Erebus, and bring an old house over your heads if you do.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: No matter, we'll bear it of with head and shoulders. 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p:
You cannot enter indeed la, gods my pittikin our 3 husbands
summon a parley; let that long old woman either creep under the bed or else stand upright behind the painted cloth.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: Do you hear: you Mabel:

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: Let's never hide our heads now, for we are discovered.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: But all this while, my honeysuckle appears not.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Why then two of them have pitched their tents there and yours lies in ambuscado with your enemy there.

sp.speaker: Hony.
sp.p: Stand upon your guard there, whilst I batter here.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Hold, I'll speak in a small voice like one of the women; here's a friend: are you up? rise, rise; stir, stir.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Uds foot, what weasel are you? are you going to catch quails, that you bring your pipes with you. I'll see what troubled ghost it is that cannot sleep.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: O mayst monopoly God save you.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Amen, for the last time I saw you, the devil was at mine elbow in buff, what! 3 merry men, and 3. merry men, and 3. merry men be we too,

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: How does my wife m. Monop.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Who? my overthwart neighbour: passing well: this is kindly done: sir Gozlin is not far from you: we'll join our armies presently, here be rare fields to walk in-captaine rise, captain Linstock bestir your stumps, for the Philestins are upon us

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: This monopoly is an arrant knave, a cogging knave, for all he's a courtier, if monopoly be suffered to ride up and down with other men's wives, he'll undo both city and country.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Moll, mask thyself, they shall not know thee.

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.p: How now sweet hearts, what make you here.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: Not that which you make here.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Marry you make bulls of your husbands.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Buzzards do we not? out you yellow infirmities: do all flowers show in your eyes like columbines.

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: Wife what says the collier? is not thy soul blacker than his coals? how does the child? how does my flesh and blood wife?

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: Your flesh and blood is very well recovered now mouse -

sp.speaker: Waf.
sp.p: I know 'tis: the collier has a sackful of news to empty.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Clare where be your two rings with diamonds?

sp.speaker: Clare,
sp.p: At hand sir, here with a wet finger.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: I dreamt you had lost hem — what a profane varlet is this shoulder clapper, to lie thus upon my wife and herrings.

sp.speaker: All. 3.
sp.p: Save you gentlemen;

sp.speaker: Tent. Hony. Waf.
sp.p: And you and our wives from you.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Your wives have ●aude themselves for one.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Mayst monopoly, though I meet you in high Germany, I hope you can understand broken English, have you discharged your debt.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Yes sir: with a double charge, your harpy that set his ten commandments upon my back had 2. Diamonds to save him harmless.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Of you sir.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Me sir, do you think there be no diamond courtiers.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: Sargent ambush issue forth, monopoly I'll cut off your convoy mayst, sergeant ambush, I charge you as you hope to receive comfort from the smell of mace speak not like a sergeant, but deal honestly, of whom had you the diamonds.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Of your wife sir if I'm an honest man.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Of me you pewter-buttoned rascal.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Siria you that live by nothing but the carrion of poultry.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: School master hark hither.

sp.speaker: Mono.
sp.p: Where are my gems and precious stones that were my bale.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Forth coming sir though your money is not, your creditor has hem.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Excellent; peace, why m. Tenterhook, if the diamonds be of the reported value, I'll pay your money receive 'em, keep 'em till mayst monopoly be fatter ith' purse: for mayst monopoly I know you will not be long empty mast. Monopoly.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Let him have 'em good Tenterhook, where are they.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: At home, I locked hem up. —

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: No indeed forsooth, I locked 'em up, and those are they your wife has, and those are they your husband (Like a bad liver as he is) would have given to a 〈◊〉 of mine, (That lies in my house to take physic) to have committed fleshly treason with her.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: I at your house — you old —

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: You perdie, and that honest bachelor, never call me old for the matter.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Motherly woman he's my husband and no bachelors buttons are at his doublet

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: 'Las, I speak innocently and that lean gentleman set in his staff there: but as I'm a sinner, both I and the young woman had an eye to the main chance, and though they brought more a bout 'em than captain Candish's voyage came to, they should not, nor could not (Unless I had been a naughty woman) have entered the straits.

sp.speaker: All. 3.
sp.p: Have we smelled you out foxes.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Do you come after us with hue and cry when you are the thieves yourselves.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Murder I see cannot be hid, but if this old sibyl of yours speak oracles, for my part, I'll be like an almanac that threatens nothing but foul weather.

sp.speaker: Tent.
sp.p: That bawd has been damned. 500 times, and is her word to be taken.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: To be damned once is enough, for any one of her coat.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Why sir. what is my coat that you fit thus upon my skirts.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Thy coat is an ancient coat, one of the seven deadly sins, put thy coat first to making; but do you hear, you mother of iniquity, you that can lose and find your ears when you list go, sail with the rest of your baudie-traffikers to the place of sixpenny sinfulness the suburbs.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: I scorn the sinfulness of any suburbs in Christendom 'tis well known I have up-rizers and down-liars within the city, night by night, like a profane fellow as thou art.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Right, I know thou hast, I'll tell you gentlefolks, there's more resort to this fortune-teller, then of forlorn wives married to old husbands, and of green-sickness wenches that can get no husbands to the house of a wise-woman. She has tricks to keep a vaulting house under the law's nose.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Thou dost the law's nose wrong to bely me so.

sp.speaker: Prentise
sp.p:
For either a cunning woman has a chamber in her house or a physician, or a picture maker, or an attorney, because all these are good cloaks for the rain. And then if the female party that's cliented above-stairs, be young, she's a squire's daughter of low degree, that lies there for physic, or comes
up to be placed with a countess: if of middle age, she's a widow, and has suits at the term or so.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: O fie upon her, burn the witch out of our company.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Let's hem her out off Brainford, if she get not the faster to London.

sp.speaker: Mab.
sp.p: O no, for god's sake, rather hem her out off London and let her keep in Brainford still.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: No you cannot hem me out of London; had I known this your rings should ha' been poxed oer — I would ha' touched 'em: I will take a pair of oars, and leave you.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Let that ruin of intemperance be raked up in dust and ashes, and now tell me, if you had raised the town, had not the tiles tumbled upon your heads: for you see your wives are chaste, these gentlemen civil, all is but a merriment, all but a may-game; she has her diamonds, you shall have your money the child is recovered, the false collier discovered, they came to Brainford to be merry, you were caught in birdlime; and therefore set the hare's-head against the goose-giblets, put all instruments in tune, and every husband play music upon the lips of his wife whilst I begin first.

sp.speaker: Omt.
sp.p: Come wenches be't so,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Mist. Justiniano's is't you were ashamed all this while of showing your face, is she your wife schoolmaster.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Look you, your schoolmaster has been in France, and lost his hair, no more parenthesis now, but Justiniano's, I will now play the merchant with you. Look not strange at her, nor at me, the story of us both, shall be as good, as an old wife's tale, to cut off our way to London. Enter chamberlain,how now?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Alas sir, the knight yonder sir Gozlin has almost his throat cut by poulterers and townsmen and rascals, and all the noise that went with him poor fellows have their fiddle-cases pulled over their ears.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Is sir Gozlin hurt?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Not much hurt sir, but he bleeds like a big, for his crown's cracked.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p:
Then has he been twice cut ith' head since we landed,
once with a pottle-po●and now with old iron.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.p: Gentlemen hasten to his rescue some, whilst others call for oars.

sp.speaker: Omn,
sp.p: Away then to London.

sp.speaker: Parenthesis
sp.l: Farewell Brainford.
Gold that buys health, can never be ill spent,
Nor hours laid out in harmless merriment.

div.head: Song.
div.l: To London hay, to London hay:
Hoist up sails and let's away,
For us to land is London shores.
Quickly shall we get to land,
If you, if you, if you,
Lend us but half a hand.
O lend us half a hand.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
